name: GlideEmailOutbound
text:
The scoped GlideEmailOutbound class implements the email object for scoped applications.
  You can use the GlideEmailOutbound methods with the email global object available in mail scripts.
  The email object behaves identically for global and scoped applications.

children.name: filter
children.text: String
children.text2:
Encoded query string in standard Glide format. See Encoded query strings. Results are case-sensitive, unless disabled using the setCaseSensitive() method.

To exclude null values from GlideFilter query results, add ISNOTEMPTY to the query condition.

children.name: Output
children.text: Number of users named Rebekah: 2

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_user'); now_GR.query(); var condition = 'first_name=rebekah'; var filter = new GlideFilter(condition, 'filterCondition'); filter.setCaseSensitive(false); var countResults = 0; while (now_GR.next()) { if (filter.match(now_GR, true)) countResults++; } gs.info('Number of users named Rebekah: ' + countResults);
children.text2: The following  shows how to filter the number of users named Rebekah.

children.name: title
children.text: String
children.text2: Descriptive title for the filter.

children.name: GlideFilter(String filter, String title)
children.text: Instantiates a GlideFilter object.

children.name: Output
children.text:
number INC0000060 is false
number INC0009002 is false
number INC0000009 is false
...
number INC0000015 is true
number INC0000016 is true
number INC0000017 is true
...

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.query(); var bool = true; while(rec.next()) { bool = GlideFilter.checkRecord(rec, "active=true"); gs.info("number "+ rec.number + " is " + bool); }
children.text2:
The following  shows how to display true for each record in the Incident table that
        meets the filter condition. False otherwise.

children.name: now_GR
children.text: GlideRecord
children.text2: GlideRecord to evaluate.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Results of the filter comparison.
  • true: Filter conditions were met.
  • false: Filter conditions were not met.

children.name: filter
children.text: String
children.text2:
Encoded query string in standard Glide format. See Encoded query strings.

To exclude null values from GlideFilter query results, add ISNOTEMPTY to the query condition.

Note: The filter values are case-sensitive. In addition, you cannot use setCaseSensitive(false) to change the change the case-sensitive value.

children.name: match
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Optional. Flag that indicates whether all conditions must be met if the filter parameter contains multiple conditions.

Valid values:

  • true: All conditions must be met for the method to return true.
  • false: Only one of the conditions must be met for the method to return true.

Default: true

children.name: checkRecord(GlideRecord now_GR, String filter, Boolean match)
children.text: Compares a specified filter to the contents of a specified GlideRecord.
children.text2:
If the specified filter contains one condition, the method returns true if the record meets the condition.

Filters support multiple conditions, for example "active=true^number=abc^category=request". You can use the match parameter to define whether all conditions must be met to determine a match or just a single condition.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Results of the match check.
  • true: Filter conditions were met.
  • false: Filter conditions were not met.

children.name: now_GR
children.text: GlideRecord
children.text2: GlideRecord to evaluate.

children.name: Output
children.text: Number of users named Rebekah: 2

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_user'); now_GR.query(); var condition = 'first_name=rebekah'; var filter = new GlideFilter(condition, 'filterCondition'); filter.setCaseSensitive(false); var countResults = 0; while (now_GR.next()) { if (filter.match(now_GR, true)) countResults++; } gs.info('Number of users named Rebekah: ' + countResults);
children.text2:
The following  shows how to ensure the filter conditions match against the
        GlideRecord provided.

children.name: match
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Flag that indicates whether all filter conditions must match.

Valid values:
  • true: All filter conditions must match.
  • false: Filter condition match is not required.

Default: false

children.name: match(GlideRecord now_GR, Boolean match)
children.text: Evaluates a filter against a specified GlideRecord.

children.name: caseSensitive
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Flag that indicates whether the filter is case-sensitive.
Valid values:
  • true: The filter is case-sensitive.
  • false: The filter is case-insensitive.

Default: true

children.name: Output
children.text:
Rebekah Padley
Rebekah Lindboe
children.text2: shows that the filter retrieves upper case results with a lower case condition.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_user'); now_GR.query(); var condition = 'first_name=rebekah'; var filter = new GlideFilter(condition, 'filterCondition'); // Disable case-sensitive filtering filter.setCaseSensitive(false); while (now_GR.next()) { if (filter.match(now_GR, true)) gs.info(now_GR.getDisplayValue()); }
children.text2: The following  shows how to disable case-sensitive results.

children.name: setCaseSensitive(Boolean caseSensitive)
children.text: Enables or disables case-sensitive filter results.

name: GlideFilter
text:
Enables filtering queries to determine if one or more records meet a specified set of
    requirements.

name: GlideFormScratchpad
text: The scoped GlideFormScratchpad class implements the g_scratchpad object for scoped applications.
text2:
The scoped GlideFormScratchpad class has no constructor and no methods. The g_scratchpad object behaves identically for global and scoped applications.

The g_scratchpad object provides a mechanism for passing information from the server to the client when the client requires information not available on a form. This can be accomplished by creating a business rule to put the information in the g_scratchpad object and accessing the information in a client script.

For an example on using this class, Example: g_scratchpad on the Developer Site.

name: GlideImportSetTransformer - Scoped, Global
text: Creates an Import Set Transformer object used to execute an Import Set Transform.
text2:
To execute an Import Set transform:
  1. Create an Import Set table using the GlideImportSetTable API.
  2. Create a Transform Map using the GlideImportSetTransformMap API.
  3. Create or use an existing Import Set using the GlideRecord API.
  4. Execute an Import Set Transform using the GlideImportSetTransformer API.
Once you have created the Import Set record it must be consumed by the GlideImportSetTransformer API in order to trigger the transform.

var transformer = new GlideImportSetTransformer(); transformer.transformAllMaps(importSetGr);

name: GlideLocale
text:
GlideLocale provides information about display information for the local
  instance.
text2: There is no constructor for a GlideLocale object. Use the get() method to get a GlideLocale object.

children.name: pluginID
children.text: String
children.text2: Unique plugin identifier.

children.name: Output
children.text:
The plugin Country Lookup Data is active
The plugin Database Replication is active
The plugin REST API Provider is active
The plugin Ten Cool Things is active

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_plugins'); var queryString = "active=0^ORactive=1"; now_GR.addEncodedQuery(queryString); now_GR.query(); var pMgr = new GlidePluginManager(); while (now_GR.next()) { var name = now_GR.getValue('name'); var pID = now_GR.getValue('source'); var isActive = pMgr.isActive(pID); if (isActive) gs.info('The plugin ' + name + ' is active'); }

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates if the plugin is active.

Valid values:
  • true: Plugin is active.
  • false: Plugin is inactive.

children.name: isActive(String pluginID)
children.text: Determines if the specified plugin has been activated.

name: GlidePluginManager
text:
The scoped GlidePluginManager API provides a method for determining if a plugin has been
  activated.

children.name: table
children.text: String
children.text2: Table to query.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user');
children.text2: This  instantiates a query of the User table.

children.name: GlideQuery(String table)
children.text: Instantiates a GlideQuery object used to build and execute record queries.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('task')     .where('active', true) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .groupBy('priority') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .aggregate('sum', 'reassignment_count') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .having('sum', 'reassignment_count', '>', 4) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .select() //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object.     .toArray(10); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result. gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  performs a query on the Task table that groups the records
        by priority, adds the numbers in the reassignment count field for each group, and returns
        groups with total reassignments greater than four.

children.name: aggregateType
children.text: String
children.text2:
The type of aggregation function to perform. Options include:
  • min: Returns the smallest value of all matching records.
  • max: Returns the largest value of all matching records.
  • sum: Returns the sum of all matching records.
  • avg: Returns the average of all matching records.
  • count: Returns the number of number of matching records.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: aggregate(String aggregateType, String field)
children.text: Aggregates a field using a specified aggregation function.
children.text2:
Use this method to build queries that aggregate against multiple fields or use multiple aggregate functions, or if you must use the groupBy() method. If you only want to aggregate against one field with one function, and you don't need to use groupBy(), then use one of these methods instead:

  • avg()
  • min()
  • max()
  • count()

children.name: Example
children.text: var faults = new global.GlideQuery('cmdb_ci') .avg('fault_count') .orElse(0); gs.info(JSON.stringify(faults));
children.text2: This  shows how to return the average number of faults in the cmdb_ci table.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object that contains the aggregate average of the given field.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: avg(String field)
children.text: Returns the aggregate average of a given numeric field.
children.text2:
You can only use this method on fields of the following types:

  • Integer
  • Long
  • Floating Point Number
  • Double
  • Currency

children.name: Example
children.text: var userCount = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .count();
children.text2: This  returns the number of active records in the User table.

children.name: Number
children.text: Number of records that match the query.

children.name: count()
children.text: Returns the number of records that match the query.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .where('last_name', 'Jeter') .deleteMultiple();
children.text2: This  deletes all active records in the User table where the last name is Jeter.

children.name: deleteMultiple()
children.text: Deletes all records in the table specified by the preceding Where clauses.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('task') .disableAutoSysFields() .insert({ description: 'example', priority: 1 });
children.text2:
This  adds a record to the task table, but does not set system fields. Without
        calling this method, the below example would update sys_updated_on, sys_mod_count, and so
        on.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: disableAutoSysFields()
children.text: Disables updating system fields, or fields with a name that starts with the sys prefix, such as sys_created_on, sys_updated_on, and sys_mod_count. Only applies to the specified query.

children.name: Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('task') .disableWorkflow() .where('active', true) .updateMultiple({ priority: 1 });
children.text2:
This  updates multiple records in the Task table without triggering any automatic
        business processes.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: disableWorkflow()
children.text:
Disables any business rules, flows, workflows, or audit records that would run or be
    created as the result of the query.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: Example
children.text: var forceUpdate = new global.GlideQuery('task') .forceUpdate() .where('sys_id', taskId) .update()
children.text2: This  force updates Task records with a certain sys_id.

children.name: forceUpdate()
children.text:
Forces a database update even when no record changes are made. For example, you can use
    this method to force a business rule to execute.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var user = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .get('5137153cc611227c000bbd1bd8cd2005', ['first_name', 'last_name']) //Returns an Optional object. .orElse({ first_name: 'Default', last_name: 'User' }); //Method in the Optional class to return a default value. gs.info(JSON.stringify(user, null, 2));
children.text2: that returns a record based on sys_id.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: key
children.text: String
children.text2: Sys_id of the record to return.

children.name: selectedFields
children.text: Array
children.text2:
Optional. Additional fields to return in the result.

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: get(String key, Array selectedFields)
children.text: Returns a single record from the query.

children.name: keyValues
children.text: Object
children.text2:
Object where the keys are the name of the fields, and the values are the values
                to query for.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var user = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .getBy({ first_name: 'Fred', last_name: 'Luddy' }, ['first_name', 'last_name', 'city', 'active']) // select first_name, last_name, city, active .orElse({ first_name: 'Nobody', last_name: 'Found', city: 'Nowhere', active: false }); gs.info(JSON.stringify(user, null, 2));
children.text2: that returns a record by querying for a user's name.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: selectedFields
children.text: Array
children.text2:
Optional. Additional fields to return in the result.

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: getBy(Object keyValues, Array selectedFields)
children.text:
Returns an Optional object containing a single record based on a set of name-value
    pairs to query by. Assumes the '=' operator for each name-value pair.

children.name: fields
children.text: String or Array of Strings
children.text2: Field or fields to group the results by.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('task')     .where('active', true) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .groupBy('priority') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .aggregate('sum', 'reassignment_count') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .having('sum', 'reassignment_count', '>', 4) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .select() //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object.     .toArray(10); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result. gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  performs a query on the Task table that groups the records
        by priority, adds the numbers in the reassignment count field for each group, and returns
        groups with total reassignments greater than four.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: groupBy(String fields)
children.text: Groups the query results by a designated field or fields.
children.text2: You must use this method with the aggregate() method.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('task')     .where('active', true) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .groupBy('priority') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .aggregate('sum', 'reassignment_count') //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .having('sum', 'reassignment_count', '>', 4) //Returns the GlideQuery object to add more attributes to the query.     .select() //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object.     .toArray(10); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result. gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  performs a query on the Task table that groups the records
        by priority, adds the numbers in the reassignment count field for each group, and returns
        groups with total reassignments greater than four.

children.name: aggregateType
children.text: String
children.text2:
The type of aggregation function to perform. Options include:
  • min: Returns the smallest value of all matching records.
  • max: Returns the largest value of all matching records.
  • sum: Returns the sum of all matching records.
  • avg: Returns the average of all matching records.
  • count: Returns the number of number of matching records.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: operator
children.text: String
children.text2:
Numeric operator to use in the operation.
Options include:
  • >: Greater than.
  • <: Less than.
  • >=: Greater than or equal to.
  • <=: Less than or equal to.
  • =: Equal to.
  • !=: Not equal to.

children.name: value
children.text: Number
children.text2: Number value to use in the operation.

children.name: having(String aggregateType, String field, String operator, Number value)
children.text:
Filters aggregate groups so that you can display only groups of results that match a
    specified condition.
children.text2: Must use this method with the aggregate() or groupBy() methods.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: keyValues
children.text: Object
children.text2:
Object containing name-value pairs to insert into the record. Unspecified
                fields will be null.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var fred = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .insert({ first_name: 'Fred', last_name: 'Luddy' }) .get(); gs.info(JSON.stringify(fred, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to insert a record based on a user's first and last name.

children.name: selectedFields
children.text: Array
children.text2:
Optional. Additional fields to return in the result.

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: insert(Object keyValues, Object selectedFields)
children.text: Inserts a record and returns an Optional object containing the record.

children.name: Example
children.text: // insert a new record var user = new GlideQuery('sys_user') .insertOrUpdate({ first_name: 'George', last_name: 'Griffey' }) .orElse(null);
children.text2:
This  shows how to insert a new record that does not already exist in the
        system.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: changes
children.text: Object
children.text2: Object containing name-value pairs to update or insert into the record.

children.name: selectedFields
children.text: Array
children.text2:
Optional. Additional fields to return in the result.

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: Example
children.text: // update existing record var user = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .insertOrUpdate({ sys_id: '2d0efd6c73662300bb513198caf6a72e', first_name: 'George', last_name: 'Griffey' }) .orElse(null);
children.text2: This  shows how to update an existing record.

children.name: insertOrUpdate(Object changes, Object selectedFields)
children.text:
Updates an existing record, or inserts a new record if one does not already
    exist.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var incidents = new global.GlideQuery('incident') .limit(5) .select('priority', 'description') .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(incidents, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to limit the results returned to five records.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: limit
children.text: Number
children.text2: Number of records to return.

children.name: limit(Number limit)
children.text: Limits the number of records returned in a query.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: Output
children.text: "Zortman"

children.name: Example
children.text: var name = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .max('last_name') .orElse(''); gs.info(JSON.stringify(name));
children.text2:
This  shows how to return the maximum value, or highest alphanumeric value, of a
        given field.

children.name: max(String field)
children.text: Returns the aggregate maximum of a given field.

children.name: Output
children.text: "Abel"

children.name: Example
children.text: var name = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .min('last_name') .orElse(''); gs.info(JSON.stringify(name));
children.text2:
This  shows how to return the minimum value, or lowest alphanumeric value, of a
        given field.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: min(String field)
children.text: Returns the aggregate minimum of a given field.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: fields
children.text: String
children.text2: Comma-delimited fields to order the result by in ascending order.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('incident') .orderBy('number') .limit(5) .select('priority', 'description') //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object. .toArray(100); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result. gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to order results in ascending order by record number.

children.name: orderBy(String fields)
children.text: Orders the returned result in ascending order by a given field.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('incident') .orderByDesc('number') .select('number', 'description') .limit(5) .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to order the result in descending order by number.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: fieldOrAggregate
children.text: String
children.text2:
If the query does not use the aggregate() method, pass the field to order the results by.

If the query uses the aggregate() method, pass the type of aggregation function to perform.

Options include:
  • min: Returns the smallest value of all matching records.
  • max: Returns the largest value of all matching records.
  • sum: Returns the sum of all matching records.
  • avg: Returns the average of all matching records.
  • count: Returns the number of number of matching records.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Optional. Field to order the result by in descending order. Required for queries using the aggregate() method.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var aggQuery = new GlideQuery('incident') .aggregate('sum', 'child_incidents') .groupBy('category') .orderByDesc('sum', 'child_incidents') .select() .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(aggQuery, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to order an aggregate result by the sum of child incidents.

children.name: orderByDesc(String fieldOrAggregate, String field)
children.text: Orders the returned result in descending order by a given field.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('failed_attempts', '>', 0) .orWhere('last_login', '<', '2019-04-15') .select() .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to add a simple OR clause to a query.

children.name: fieldOrQuery
children.text: String or GlideQuery
children.text2: Field or another GlideQuery object used in the where clause. If passing a field, you can dot-walk to a desired value. For example, 'company.name'.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: // active = true OR (title = 'Vice President' AND state = 'CA') var query = new GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .orWhere(new GlideQuery() .where('title', 'Vice President') .where('state', 'CA')) .select('name') .limit(5) .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2: This shows how to add a orWhere clause that contains a separate query.

children.name: operator
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional. Operator used in the OR clause. If you do not pass an argument, the
                system uses the = operator. You do not need to include a placeholder value.

children.name: value
children.text: Any
children.text2: Value used in the OR clause.

children.name: orWhere(String fieldOrQuery, String operator, Any value)
children.text: Adds an OR clause to a query that returns values based on a given condition.
children.text2: Note: Precede this method with the where(), whereNull(), or whereNotNull() methods.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field used in the query.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .whereNotNull('first_name') .orWhereNotNull('last_name') .select() .limit(5) .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to query the User table and return results where the first and last
        names are not null.

children.name: orWhereNotNull(String field)
children.text:
Adds an OR clause that returns records that do not contain a null value in a given
    field.
children.text2: Note: Precede this method with the where(), whereNull(), or whereNotNull() methods.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .whereNull('last_name') .orWhereNull('first_name') .select() .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to query the User table and return records where the first or last
        names are null.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field used in the query.

children.name: orWhereNull(String field)
children.text:
Adds an OR clause to a query that returns records that contain a null value in a given
    field.
children.text2: Note: Precede this method with the where(), whereNull(), or whereNotNull() methods.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: GlideQuery object containing the encoded query.

children.name: table
children.text: String
children.text2: Table to query, such as task or incident.

children.name: Example
children.text: GlideQuery.parse('task', 'active=true^ORDERBYpriority') // Pass the encoded query to use to parse the Task records .select('description') // Return the records that match the encoded query .forEach(doSomething); // Do some processing on each of the returned records
children.text2:
The following  creates a GlideQuery object that contains all active records in the
        task table, ordered by the priority field, returned as a Stream object that contains just
        the description field.

children.name: encoded_query
children.text: String
children.text2: Encoded query to apply to the records in the specified table.

children.name: parse(String table, String encoded_query )
children.text: Adds an encoded query to a new GlideQuery query.
children.text2:
This method does not support all GlideRecord encoded query operators. The following operators are currently supported:

= ANYTHING GT_FIELD NOT IN
!= BETWEEN GT_OR_EQUALS_FIELD NOT LIKE
> CONTAINS IN NSAMEAS
>= DOES NOT CONTAIN INSTANCEOF ON
< DYNAMIC LIKE SAMEAS
<= EMPTYSTRING LT_FIELD STARTSWITH
  ENDSWITH LT_OR_EQUALS_FIELD

children.name: Stream
children.text: Object used to interact with a stream of items such as records.

children.name: fields
children.text: String or Array of Strings
children.text2:
Optional. Fields to display in the result. You can provide any number of fields as arguments, dot-walk to a desired value, or use a flag. For example: 
select('first_name', 'location.city', 'company$DISPLAY');
or
select(['first_name', 'location.city', 'company$DISPLAY']);

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var stream = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .select('first_name', 'last_name', 'company$DISPLAY') .toArray(5); gs.info(JSON.stringify(stream, null, 2));
children.text2: This shows how to select fields to display from the query and use $DISPLAY to return the display value of a field.

children.name: select(String fields)
children.text: Returns the results of the query as a Stream object containing the specified fields.
children.text2:
Note: Use a terminal method in the Stream class to get the result of the query. For more information, see Stream.

You can append a flag to a field name to return the field's metadata instead of the field's value. For example, using the field name company$DISPLAY returns the display value of a company field. Possible flags include:

  • DISPLAY: Returns the display value of a field.
  • CURRENCY_CODE: Returns the currency code of a currency field. For example, USD.
  • CURRENCY_DISPLAY: Returns the currency display value of a currency field. For example, ¥123.45.
  • CURRENCY_STRING: Returns the currency string of a currency field. For example, JPY;123.45.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: fields
children.text: String or Array of Strings
children.text2:
Optional. Fields to display in the result. You can provide any number of fields as arguments, dot-walk to a desired value, or use a flag. For example: 
selectOne('first_name', 'location.city', 'company$DISPLAY');
or
selectOne(['first_name', 'location.city', 'company$DISPLAY']);

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var user = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('zip', '12345') .whereNotNull('last_name') .selectOne('first_name', 'last_name', 'company$DISPLAY') .get(); gs.info(JSON.stringify(user, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to return a single record as an Optional object and display
        specified fields.

children.name: selectOne(String fields)
children.text: Returns the result of the query as an Optional object containing specified fields.
children.text2:
Use this method when returning a single record, or to test if a record exists. If returning multiple records, use the select() method to return a Stream object.

You can append a flag to a field name to return the field's metadata instead of the field's value. For example, using the field name company$DISPLAY returns the display value of a company field. Possible flags include:

  • DISPLAY: Returns the display value of a field.
  • CURRENCY_CODE: Returns the currency code of a currency field. For example, USD.
  • CURRENCY_DISPLAY: Returns the currency display value of a currency field. For example, ¥123.45.
  • CURRENCY_STRING: Returns the currency string of a currency field. For example, JPY;123.45.

children.name: Example
children.text: var totalFaults = new global.GlideQuery('cmdb_ci') .sum('fault_count') .orElse(0); gs.info(JSON.stringify(totalFaults));
children.text2: This  shows how to return the sum of all faults in the cmdb_ci table.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field on which to perform the operation.

children.name: sum(String field)
children.text: Returns the aggregate sum of a given numeric field.
children.text2:
You can only use this method on fields of the following types:

  • Integer
  • Long
  • Floating Point Number
  • Double
  • Currency

children.name: Example
children.text: var userGr = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .whereNotNull('first_name') .limit(10) .toGlideRecord(); userGr.query();
children.text2: This  shows how to transform a GlideQuery object into a GlideRecord.

children.name: or
children.text: GlideRecord object that contains the query. If you used the GlideQuery.aggregate() method, then the method returns a GlideAggregrate object instead.

children.name: toGlideRecord()
children.text: Returns a GlideRecord object that represents the current query. Returns a GlideAggregrate object if the query uses the GlideQuery.aggregate() method.
children.text2: After transforming the query, use the query() method in the GlideRecord or GlideAggregate classes to query the database.

children.name: changes
children.text: Object
children.text2:
Object containing name-value pairs to update in the record. Names must match
                  fields in the table.

children.name: Example
children.text: var updateRecord = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('sys_id', '0a826bf03710200044e0bfc8bcbe5d7a') .update({ city: 'Los Angeles' });
children.text2: This  shows how to update a record with new values.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object used to interact with a single record.

children.name: selectedFields
children.text: Array
children.text2:
Optional. Additional fields to return in the result.

Default: The system always returns the sys_id.

children.name: update(Object changes, Object selectedFields)
children.text: Updates an existing record that matches the defined conditions.
children.text2: Before using this method, call the where() method to specify the conditions that a record must meet to be updated.

children.name: Output
children.text: {"rowCount":1}

children.name: Example
children.text: var update = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', false) .where('last_name', 'Griffey') .updateMultiple({ active: true }); gs.info(JSON.stringify(update));
children.text2: This  shows how to update any records that fit a defined criteria.

children.name: Object
children.text:
Object containing the number of records that were updated. Keys include:
  • rowCount: Number of rows updated in the table.

children.name: changes
children.text: Object
children.text2:
Object containing name-value pairs to update in the record. Names must match
                  fields in the table.

children.name: updateMultiple(Object changes)
children.text:
Updates all existing records that match the defined conditions. Returns the number of
    records updated.
children.text2: Before using this method, call the where() method to specify the conditions that the records must meet to be updated.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .where('last_login', '>', '2016-04-15') .limit(5) .select() .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to return records from the User table where active is true and the
        user last logged on after a specified date.

children.name: fieldOrQuery
children.text: String or GlideQuery
children.text2: Field or another GlideQuery object used in the where clause. If passing a field, you can dot-walk to a desired value. For example, 'company.name'.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: // active = true AND (priority = 1 OR severity = 1) var query = new GlideQuery('incident') .where('active', true) .where(new GlideQuery() .where('priority', 1) .orWhere('severity', 1)) .limit(5) .select() .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to return records from the Incident table where active is true and
        where either the priority or the severity is 1.

children.name: operator
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional. Operator used in the where clause. If you do not pass an argument,
                the system uses the = operator.

children.name: value
children.text: Any
children.text2: Value used in the where clause.

children.name: where(String fieldOrQuery, String operator, Any value)
children.text:
Adds a Where clause to the query that returns values based on a given
    condition.
children.text2: Note: Do not precede this method with the orWhere(), orWhereNull(), or orWhereNotNull() methods.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .whereNotNull('first_name') .select() .limit(5) .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to query the User table and return results where the first_name
        field is not null.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field used in the query.

children.name: whereNotNull(String field)
children.text: Returns records that do not contain a null value in a given field.
children.text2: Note: Do not precede this method with the orWhere(), orWhereNull(), or orWhereNotNull() methods.

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2: Field used in the query.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var query = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .whereNull('last_name') .orWhereNull('first_name') .select() .toArray(100) gs.info(JSON.stringify(query, null, 2));
children.text2:
This  shows how to query the User table and return records where the first or last
        names are null.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: whereNull(String field)
children.text: Returns records that contain a null value in a given field.
children.text2: Note: Do not precede this method with the orWhere(), orWhereNull(), or orWhereNotNull() methods.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var users = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .withAcls() .limit(5) .orderByDesc('first_name') .select('first_name') .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(users, null, 2));
children.text2: This  shows how to execute a secure query using ACLs.

children.name: GlideQuery
children.text: The query object being built.

children.name: withAcls()
children.text: Executes the query using the GlideRecordSecure API to securely query the database while honoring ACLs.

name: GlideQuery
text: The GlideQuery API is an alternative to GlideRecord to perform CRUD operations on record data from server-side scripts.
text2:
The GlideQuery API lets you:

  • Use standard JavaScript objects and types for queries and results.
  • Quickly diagnose query errors with additional checks and clear error messages.
  • Simplify your code by avoiding boiler-plate query patterns.
  • Avoid common performance issues without needing deeper knowledge of GlideRecord.


Use the GlideQuery API in scoped or global server-side scripts. When used within a scoped app, it must be prefixed with the global scope. 
new global.GlideQuery('sys_user')
// ...
This API requires the GlideQuery [com.sn_glidequery] plugin.

Implementation

This API works together with the Stream and Optional APIs in a builder pattern where the method calls chain together, each method building on the returned result of the previous method. Use methods to define the attributes of the query. The methods do not execute until you call a terminal method, a method that returns a query result, allowing you to define the requirements of the query before executing it.

If the query returns a single record, the system wraps the result in an Optional object. If the query returns a stream of records, the system wraps the result in a Stream object. These objects let you manage the result using a set of methods in each API.

For example, here's a script that performs a query on the Task table and groups the records by priority and returns groups with total reassignments greater than four.

var query = new global.GlideQuery('task')
    .where('active', true) //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "where" clause.
    .groupBy('priority') //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "group by" clause.
    .aggregate('sum', 'reassignment_count') //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "sum(reassignment_count)" clause.
    .having('sum', 'reassignment_count', '>', 4) //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "having reassignment_count > 4" clause.
    .select() //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object.  
    .toArray(10); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result.


Error handling

The GlideQuery API throws an error when your query has a problem, and includes a clear explanation to help guide you. GlideQuery checks for:

  • Invalid fields
  • Invalid value types for a field
  • Invalid values for choice fields
  • Invalid query operators

For example, this code sample would throw an error because the queried field does not exist in the table.

new global.GlideQuery('task')
    .where('id', '4717dfe5a9fe198100450448b2404c16') // should be 'sys_id'
    .select('description', 'severity')
    .toArray(100);
  // Error: Unable to find field 'id' in table 'task'. Known fields: active, activity_due, ...

This code sample would throw an error because the data type of one of the arguments is incorrect.

new global.GlideQuery('task')
    .where('priority', 'one') // priority is an integer (should be 1)
    .select('description', 'severity')
    .toArray(100);
  // Error: Unable to match value ['one'] with field 'priority' in table 'task'. Expecting type 'integer'


Reuse

Because GlideQuery objects are immutable, you can reuse them later in other parts of your code. For example, this script creates a query and then uses the GlideQuery object later to generate a report.

var highPriorityTasks = new global.GlideQuery('task')
    .where('active', true)
    .where('priority', 1);

generateReport(highPriorityTasks);
notifyOwners(highPriorityTasks);
var avgReassignmentCount = highPriorityTasks
    .avg('reassignment_count')
    .orElse(0)


Limitations

The GlideQuery API does not support:

  • Reading or writing to tables that do not allow access from other scopes.
  • Reading encoded queries.
  • GlideDate or GlideDateTime objects, which are read as JavaScript strings.
  • FX currency fields.
  • Updating journal field types.
  • Queries with ambiguous conditional logic. For example, the following query is unclear because the system does not know whether to execute (active = true AND name != null) OR last_name = Luddy or active = true AND (name != null OR last_name = Luddy). 
    var user = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user')
  .where('active', true)
  .whereNotNull('name')
  .orWhere('last_name', 'Luddy')
  .selectOne()
  .get()

    See the where() method to understand how to nest a child query instead.

Note: Because the GlideQuery API converts GlideRecord objects into standard JavaScript objects, it may take longer to execute queries. To reduce performance issues, avoid creating loops that iterate over large numbers of records.

children.name: GlideQueryCondition
children.text:
A reference to a GlideQueryConditon that was added to the
                  GlideRecord.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of a field.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); var qc = now_GR.addQuery('category', 'Hardware'); qc.addCondition('category', 'Network'); now_GR.addQuery('number','INC0000003'); now_GR.next(); now_GR.number; gs.info(now_GR.getEncodedQuery());

children.name: oper
children.text: String
children.text2:
(Optional) The operator for the query. If you do not specify an operator, the
                condition uses an equals operator.

children.name: value
children.text: Object

children.text: Adds an AND condition to the current condition.
children.text2:
Table 2. Returns
Type Description
GlideQueryCondition A reference to a GlideQueryConditon that was added to the GlideRecord.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); var qc = now_GR.addQuery('category', 'Hardware'); qc.addOrCondition('category', 'Network'); now_GR.addQuery('number','INC0000003'); now_GR.next(); now_GR.number; gs.info(now_GR.getEncodedQuery());

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Field name

children.text:
A reference to a GlideQueryConditon that was added to the
                  GlideRecord.

children.name: Example
children.text: var myObj = new GlideRecord('incident'); var q1 = myObj.addQuery('state', '<', 3); q1.addOrCondition('state', '>', 5); var q2 = myObj.addQuery('priority', 1); q2.addOrCondition('priority', 5); myObj.query();
children.text2:
To group AND/OR statements to make complex queries, such as "All incidents with a (state
        less than 3 OR greater than 5) AND (priority is 1 OR priority is 5)

children.name: oper
children.text: String
children.text2:
(Optional) Query operator. The available values are dependent on the data type of the value parameter.
Numbers:
  • =
  • !=
  • >
  • >=
  • <
  • <=
Strings (must be in upper case):
  • =
  • !=
  • IN
  • STARTSWITH
  • ENDSWITH
  • CONTAINS
  • DOESNOTCONTAIN

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2:
Value on which to query (not case-sensitive).
Note: All passed in arrays must contain a minimum of two elements. Single element arrays are not supported.

children.name: addOrCondition(String name, String oper, Object value)
children.text:
Appends a two-or-three parameter OR condition to an existing
    GlideQueryCondition.
children.text2:
addOrCondition() works in conjunction with any of the addQuery() methods to OR the specified query parameters to the query previously constructed using addQuery().

addOrCondition() is typically called with three parameters; table field, operator, and comparison value. It can be called with only two parameters, table field and comparison value, such as qc.addOrCondition('category', 'software');. The operator in this case is assumed to be "equal to".

Table 1. Parameters
Name Type Description
name String Field name
oper String (Optional) Query operator. The available values are dependent on the data type of the value parameter.
Numbers:
  • =
  • !=
  • >
  • >=
  • <
  • <=
Strings (must be in upper case):
  • =
  • !=
  • IN
  • STARTSWITH
  • ENDSWITH
  • CONTAINS
  • DOESNOTCONTAIN
value Object Value on which to query (not case-sensitive).
Note: All passed in arrays must contain a minimum of two elements. Single element arrays are not supported.

Table 2. Returns
Type Description
GlideQueryCondition A reference to a GlideQueryConditon that was added to the GlideRecord.

name: GlideQueryCondition
text:
The scoped GlideQueryCondition API provides additional AND or OR conditions that can be
    added to the current condition, allowing you to build complex queries.
text2:
Build complex queries such as:
category='hardware' OR category='software' AND priority='2' AND priority='1'


In the case of addCondition(), an implied AND is added.

This class has no constructor. A GlideQueryCondition object is returned by the following methods:
  • addActiveQuery()
  • addInactiveQuery()
  • addJoinQuery()
  • addNotNullQuery()
  • addNullQuery()
  • addQuery()


If there is a complicated set of AND and OR queries, a single encoded query containing all conditions simplifies the query creation. To simplify the query creation, create a query in a list view, right-click the query, and select Copy query. It creates a single encoded query string to return your result set. Use that string as a parameter in an addEncodedQuery() call.

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident');

children.text2:
Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.name: function
children.text: Object
children.text2: GlideDBFunctionBuilder object that defines a SQL operation.

children.name: Example
children.text: var functionBuilder = new GlideDBFunctionBuilder(); var myAddingFunction = functionBuilder.add(); myAddingFunction = functionBuilder.field('order'); myAddingFunction = functionBuilder.field('priority'); myAddingFunction = functionBuilder.build(); // Query incidents in which order + priority is less than 5 and display that added value var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addFunction(myAddingFunction); now_GR.addQuery(myAddingFunction, '<', 5); now_GR.query(); while(now_GR.next()) gs.info(now_GR.getValue(myAddingFunction));

children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: addFunction(Object function)
children.text: Applies a pre-defined GlideDBFunctionBuilder object to a record.
children.text2: Use the GlideDBFunctionBuilder scoped class to define a function. After the function is defined, use the addFunction(Object function) method to apply the function to a record.

children.name: GlideQueryCondition
children.text: Filter that lists records where the relationships match.

children.name: Example
children.text: var prob = new GlideRecord('problem'); prob.addJoinQuery('incident'); prob.query();
children.text2:
Find problems that have an incident attached. This  returns problems that have
        associated incidents. However, it won't pull values from the incidents that are returned as
        a part of the query.

children.name: joinTable
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of table to use in the join, such as 'incident'.

children.name: Example
children.text: // Look for Problem records that have associated Incident records var now_GR = new GlideRecord('problem'); var grSQ = now_GR.addJoinQuery('incident'); // Where the Problem records are "active=false" now_GR.addQuery('active', 'false'); // And the Incident records are "active=true" grSQ.addCondition('active', 'true'); // Query now_GR.query(); // Iterate and output results while (now_GR.next()) { gs.info(now_GR.getValue('number')); }
children.text2: Find inactive problems with associated incidents.

children.name: primaryField
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional. Name of the field in the GlideRecord to use to join the field specified in the joinTableField parameter.

Default: sys_id

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('problem'); now_GR.addJoinQuery('incident', 'opened_by', 'caller_id'); now_GR.query();
children.text2: Find problems that have incidents associated where the incident caller_id field value matches that of the problem opened_by field.

children.name: joinTableField
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional. Name of the field in the table specified in joinTable to use to join the tables.

Default: First field in the table specified in joinTable that is a reference field to the current GlideRecord table.

children.name: addJoinQuery(String joinTable, String primaryField, String joinTableField)
children.text:
Adds a filter to return records based on a relationship in a table related to the
    current GlideRecord.
children.text2:
You can use this method to find all the users that are in the database group via the Group Member [sys_user_grmember] table, or to find all problems that have an assigned incident via the incident.problem_id relationship.

This is not a true database join; rather, addJoinQuery() adds a subquery. So, while the result set is limited based on the join, the only fields that you have access to are those on the base table (those which are in the table with which the GlideRecord was initialized.)

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

Adds a filter to return records where the value of the specified field is

children.text2:
Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2:
Table field name. If you are not querying a table field, use these reserved variables:
  • 123TEXTQUERY321: Adds a search term to the query. Use this option to return matching values from any field in the table. Use the term you want to query as the value.
  • 123TEXTINDEXGROUP321: Adds a text index group to the query. Use the name of the text index group from the Text Index Groups [ts_index_group] table you want to query as the value. For more information about text index groups, see Configure multiple tables for indexing and searching.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.addQuery('active', true); rec.query(); while (rec.next()) { rec.setValue('active', false); rec.update(); }
children.text2:
This code  shows how to query the active records in the incident table and then set
        them all to inactive.

children.name: GlideQueryCondition
children.text: Query condition added to the GlideRecord.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord("kb_knowledge); now_GR.addQuery("123TEXTQUERY321", "email server"); now_GR.addQuery("123TEXTINDEXGROUP321", "portal"); now_GR.query();
children.text2: Adds a query for records in the kb_knowledge table and portal text index group.

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2: Value on which to query (not case-sensitive).

children.name: addQuery(String name, Object value)
children.text: Build a search query and return the rows that match the request.
children.text2:
If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the GlideQueryCondition method addOrCondition().

When addQuery() is called with only two parameters, table name and comparison value, such as myObj.addQuery('category','Hardware');, the operator is assumed to be "equal to".

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.addQuery('active',true); rec.addQuery('sys_created_on', ">", "2010-01-19 04:05:00"); rec.query(); while (rec.next()) { rec.setValue('active', false); gs.info('Active incident ' + rec.getValue('number') + ' closed'); rec.update(); }

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Table field name.

children.name: GlideQueryCondition
children.text: The query condition that was added to the GlideRecord.
