children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addQuery('number','IN','INC00001,INC00002'); now_GR.query(); while(now_GR.next()) { //do something.... }
children.text2: Using the IN operator.

children.name: operator
children.text: String
children.text2:
Query operator. The available values are dependent on the data type of the value parameter.
Numbers:
  • =
  • !=
  • >
  • >=
  • <
  • <=
Strings (must be in upper case):
  • =
  • !=
  • IN
  • NOT IN
  • STARTSWITH
  • ENDSWITH
  • CONTAINS
  • DOES NOT CONTAIN
  • INSTANCEOF

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2: Value on which to query (not case-sensitive).

children.name: addQuery(String name, String operator, Object value)
children.text:
Provides the ability to build a request, which when executed, returns the rows from the
    specified table, that match the request.
children.text2:
If you are familiar with SQL, this method is similar to the "where" clause. One or more addQuery() calls can be made in a single query; in this case the queries are AND'ed. If any of the query statements need to be OR'ed, use the GlideQueryCondition method addOrCondition().

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.addQuery('active=true'); rec.query(); while (rec.next()) { rec.setValue('active', false); gs.info('Active incident ' + rec.getValue('number') + ' closed'); rec.update(); }

children.name: GlideQueryCondition
children.text: The query condition added to the GlideRecord.

children.name: query
children.text: String
children.text2: An encoded query string .

children.name: addQuery(String query)
children.text: Adds a filter to return records using an encoded query string.
children.text2:
Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: field
children.text: String
children.text2:
The name of the field in this GlideRecord to modify.

If the associated field is not a numeric type, the operation is ignored.

children.name: Example
children.text: gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // ”1” now_GR.addValue(”u_count”, 1); now_GR.update(); now_GR.get(now_GR.sys_id); // The record must be reloaded from the database to observe the result gs.info(now_GR.u_count);
children.text2: Shows a value being added.

children.name: value
children.text: Number
children.text2:
The amount to add to the value when the record is saved. To perform a
                subtraction operation, simply pass a negative value.

children.name: Example
children.text: gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // "4" now_GR.addValue(”u_count”, -1); now_GR.update(); now_GR.get(now_GR.sys_id); // The record must be reloaded from the database to observe the result gs.info(now_GR.u_count);
children.text2: Shows a value being subtracted.

children.name: addValue(String field, Number value)
children.text:
Provides atomic add and subtract operations on a specified number field at the database
    level for the current GlideRecord object.
children.text2:
Typically, a GlideRecord object is written as one record in a database. Individual field values are stored as defined. For code that adds a value to a GlideRecord field, it simply saves the field to the database with the new value, rather than atomically incrementing it.

For example, when the following code is executed, the value of the u_count field in the database is 2.

gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // "1" 
now_GR.u_count += 1;
now_GR.update();
now_GR.get(now_GR.sys_id);
gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // "2"
If another user concurrently runs identical code, instead of the two operations each adding 1 to u_count, the net effect is that u_count only contains 2, with one operation's update actually being lost.

Conversely, the addValue() method performs the addition/subtraction in the database when the record is updated as an atomic operation. Two operations running concurrently each properly update the field. 

gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // "1" 
now_GR.addValue(”u_count”, 1); 
now_GR.update(); 
now_GR.get(now_GR.sys_id); // The record must be reloaded from the database to observe the result
gs.info(now_GR.u_count); // "3", if executed concurrently with another user

Note: The new value is not read back from the database unless explicitly done so.

Like setValue(), addValue() changes only take effect in the database after a subsequent call to update() or insert(). If insert() is called, the specified field is initialized with the value parameter passed into addValue().

Note: If setValue() is called for the specified field prior to calling addValue(), the addValue() method is not processed and an error message is logged.

children.name: Example
children.text: function createAcl(table, role) { gs.info("Checking security on table " + table); var now_GR = new GlideRecord("sys_security_acl"); now_GR.addQuery("name", table); now_GR.addQuery("operation", "read"); now_GR.query(); var encQuery = now_GR.getEncodedQuery(); if (now_GR.next()) { // existing acl found so use it createAclRole(now_GR.getValue('sys_id'), role); return; } else { now_GR.initialize(); now_GR.applyEncodedQuery(encQuery); var acl = now_GR.insert(); gs.info("Added read access control on " + table); createAclRole(acl, role); } }

children.name: queryString
children.text: String
children.text2: Encoded query to apply to the current GlideRecord.

children.name: applyEncodedQuery(String queryString)
children.text:
Sets the values of the specified encoded query terms and applies them to the current
    GlideRecord.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); gs.info(now_GR.canCreate());
children.text2:
This code  writes whether the current user can create records in the Incident table
        in the system log.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the user's roles permit creating of records in this table.
Valid values:
  • true: Creating permitted
  • false: Creating is not permitted

children.name: canCreate()
children.text:
Determines if the Access Control Rules, which include the user's roles, permit
    inserting new records in this table.

children.name: Example
children.text: var att = new GlideRecord('sys_attachment'); gs.info(att.canDelete());
children.text2:
This code  writes whether the current user can delete records in the Incident table
        in the system log.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the user's roles permit deleting of records in this table.
Valid values:
  • true: Deleting permitted
  • false: Deleting is not permitted

children.name: canDelete()
children.text:
Determines if the Access Control Rules, which include the user's roles, permit deleting
    records in this table.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); gs.info(now_GR.canRead());
children.text2:
This code  writes whether the current user can read records in the Incident table in
        the system log.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the user's roles permit reading of records in this table.
Valid values:
  • true: Reading permitted
  • false: Reading is not permitted

children.name: canRead()
children.text:
Determines if the Access Control Rules, which include the user's roles, permit reading
    records in this table.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); gs.info(now_GR.canWrite());
children.text2:
This code  writes whether the current user can write records in the Incident table
        in the system log.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the user's roles permit writing of records in this table.
Valid values:
  • true: Writing permitted
  • false: Writing is not permitted

children.name: canWrite()
children.text:
Determines if the Access Control Rules, which include the user's roles, permit editing
    records in this table.

children.name: Output
children.text:
*** Script: INC0000003 is within window
*** Script: INC0000004 is within window

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.orderBy('number'); now_GR.chooseWindow(2, 4); now_GR.query(); while (now_GR.next()) { gs.info(now_GR.getValue('number') + ' is within window'); }
children.text2: This  show returning records 3 and 4 from the Incident table.

children.name: firstRow
children.text: Number
children.text2:
First row to include. Because the index starts at 0, a value of 0 returns the
                first row.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: lastRow
children.text: Number
children.text2:
0-based row number of the first row NOT to return. Behaves similar to Java's String.substring(a,b) method.

For example, if lastRow = 4 and firstRow = 2, two records are returned (4-2).

children.name: forceCount
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Optional. Flag that indicates whether to force a row count query. In most implementations of this call, the row count is performed. There are some outlying cases, such as text searches, were a row count is not performed. Setting this flag ensures that the row count occurs.
Valid values:
  • true: Row count always occurs.
  • false: Row count occurs if implemented in normal execution of method.

Default: false

children.name: chooseWindow(Number firstRow, Number lastRow, Boolean forceCount)
children.text: Sets a range of rows to be returned by subsequent queries.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addQuery('active','false'); // To delete all inactive incidents now_GR.query(); now_GR.deleteMultiple();

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: deleteMultiple()
children.text: Deletes multiple records that satisfy the query condition.
children.text2:
This method does not delete attachments.

Do not use deleteMultiple() on tables with currency fields, delete these records individually. Also, do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); //to delete one record if (now_GR.get('99ebb4156fa831005be8883e6b3ee4b9')) now_GR.deleteRecord();

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the record was successfully deleted.
Valid values:
  • true: Record was deleted.
  • false: No record was found to delete.

children.name: deleteRecord()
children.text: Deletes the current record.

children.name: Example
children.text: var grIncident = new GlideRecord('incident'); var returnValue = grIncident.get('99ebb4156fa831005be8883e6b3ee4b9'); gs.info(returnValue); // logs true or false gs.info(grIncident.short_description); // logs Incident Short description
children.text2: This  shows how to obtain an incident record by passing in the sys_id.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Indicates whether the requested record was located:
  • true: record was found
  • false: record was not found

children.name: name
children.text: Object
children.text2: Optional. Name of the instantiated GlideRecord column to search for the specified value parameter. If only a single parameter is passed in, the method assumes that this parameter is the sys_id or display value.

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2: Value to match.

children.name: Example
children.text: var grIncident = new GlideRecord('incident'); var returnValue = grIncident.get('caller_id.name','Sylivia Wayland'); gs.info(returnValue); // logs true or false gs.info(grIncident.getValue('number')); // logs Incident Number
children.text2:
This  shows how to obtain an incident record by passing the field to search
        (caller_id.name) and the value to match within that field.

children.name: get(Object name, Object value)
children.text: Returns the specified record in the current GlideRecord object.
children.text2:
This method accepts either one or two parameters. If only a single parameter is passed in, the method assumes that it is the sys_id of the desired record. If not found, it then tries to match the value against the display value. If two parameters are passed in, the first is the name of the column within the GlideRecord to search. The second is the value to search for.

If multiple records are found, use next() to access the additional records.

children.name: fieldName
children.text: String
children.text2: Field name for which to return the dictionary attributes

children.name: Example
children.text: doit(); function doit() { var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_user'); now_GR.query("user_name","admin"); if (now_GR.next()) { gs.info("we got one"); gs.info(now_GR.location.getAttribute("tree_picker")); } }

children.name: String
children.text: Dictionary attributes

children.name: getAttribute(String fieldName)
children.text: Returns the dictionary attributes for the specified field.

children.name: Output
children.text: The table label is Incident.

children.name: Example
children.text: // Display the incident table label var now_GR = new GlideRecord("incident"); var value = now_GR.getClassDisplayValue(); gs.info("The table label is " + value + ".");
children.text2: This  prints the label of the passed in table.

children.name: String
children.text: Label that identifies the table.

children.name: getClassDisplayValue()
children.text: Returns the current table's label.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.get('sys_id','<sys_id>'); gs.info(now_GR.getDisplayValue());
children.text2: This  writes the display value of a specified incident record into the log.

children.name: String
children.text: Display value for the current record.

children.name: getDisplayValue()
children.text: Retrieves the display value for the current record.
children.text2:
Display values are manipulated based on the actual value in the database and user or system settings and preferences.

The display value that is returned is dependent on the field type.

  • Choice fields: The database value may be a number, but the display value will be more descriptive.
  • Date fields: The database value is in UTC format, while the display value is based on the user's time zone.
  • Encrypted text: The database value is encrypted, while the displayed value is unencrypted based on the user's encryption context.
  • Reference fields: The database value is sys_id, but the display value is a display field of the referenced record.

children.name: Output
children.text: Label is - Priority

children.name: Example
children.text: var grInc = new GlideRecord('incident'); grInc.get('sys_id','ef43c6d40a0a0b5700c77f9bf387afe3'); var field = grInc.getElement('priority'); var ed = field.getED(); var isEdge = ed.getLabel(); gs.info("Label is - " + isEdge);
children.text2: This  shows how to retrieve the name field for an incident GlideRecord.

children.name: GlideElementDescriptor
children.text: The element's descriptor.

children.name: getED()
children.text: Returns the element's descriptor.

children.name: Output
children.text: My DB is not working

children.name: Example
children.text: var elementName = 'short_description'; var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.newRecord(); now_GR.setValue(elementName, "My DB is not working"); now_GR.insert(); var sdesc = now_GR.getElement('short_description'); gs.info(sdesc.getValue());
children.text2: The following shows how to add a new incident record with details in the Short Description field.

children.name: GlideElement
children.text:
The GlideElement for the specified column of
                the current record. Each object describes a field in the current
                GlideRecord.

children.name: fieldName
children.text: String
children.text2: Column name for which to return the GlideElement object.

children.name: getElement(String fieldName)
children.text: Retrieves the GlideElement object for the specified field.
children.text2:
The value returned by this method is a complete GlideElement object. The results are the equivalent of dot-walking a field value. For example, now_GR.getElement('short_description') provides the same result as nowGR.short_description.

In most cases, do not use dot-walking to get values from a record. Dot-walking retrieves the entire object instead of the field value. Retrieving the object uses much more storage and might cause undesirable results when used in arrays or in Service Portal.

Instead of retrieving the entire object, you can use one of the following methods to copy the field values:

  • getValue()
  • getDisplayValue()

If dot-walking through a GlideElement object is necessary, use the toString() method to retrieve values. For example, you might need the current caller's manager sys_id to set another reference field. The following example shows how to get the string value instead of the entire object:

var mgr = current.caller_id.manager.toString();

See also:

  • GlideElement – toString()
  • getElements()

children.name: Array
children.text: Array of GlideElement objects. Each object describes a field in the current GlideRecord.

children.name: Output
children.text:
delivery_time_var
delivery_time
sequence
priority
assigned_group

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('question'); var elementArr = now_GR.getElements(); now_GR.orderByDesc('sys_created_on'); now_GR.setLimit(5); now_GR.query(); while (now_GR.next()){ var qNames = now_GR.name.toString(); elementArr.push(qNames); gs.info(qNames); }
children.text2:
The following  displays the value of the name field for the five most recent records
        created in the Question [question] table.

children.name: getElements()
children.text:
Returns an array of GlideElement objects. Each object describes a field in the current
    GlideRecord.
children.text2:
If dot-walking through a GlideElement object is necessary, use the toString() method to retrieve values. For example, you might need the current caller's manager sys_id to set another reference field. The following example shows how to get the string value instead of the entire object:

var mgr = current.caller_id.manager.toString();

See also:

  • GlideElement – toString()
  • getElement()

children.name: Output
children.text: active=true^priority=1

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addQuery('active', true); now_GR.addQuery('priority', 1); now_GR.query(); var encodedQuery = now_GR.getEncodedQuery(); gs.info(encodedQuery);

children.name: getEncodedQuery()
children.text: Retrieves the query condition of the current result set as an encoded query string.
children.text2: For details, see Encoded query strings.

children.name: Example
children.text: template.print("Summary of Requested items:\n"); var now_GR = new GlideRecord("sc_req_item"); now_GR.addQuery("request", current.sysapproval); now_GR.query(); while(now_GR.next()) { var nicePrice = now_GR.price.toString(); if (nicePrice != '') { nicePrice = parseFloat(nicePrice); nicePrice = nicePrice.toFixed(2); } template.print(now_GR.number + ": " + now_GR.quantity + " X " + now_GR.cat_item.getDisplayValue() + " at $" + nicePrice + " each \n"); template.print(" Options:\n"); for (key in now_GR.variables) { var now_V = now_GR.variables[key]; if(now_V.getGlideObject().getQuestion().getLabel() != '') { template.space(4); template.print(' ' + now_V.getGlideObject().getQuestion().getLabel() + " = " + now_V.getDisplayValue() + "\n"); } } }

children.name: String
children.text: Field's label

children.name: getLabel()
children.text: Returns the field's label.

children.name: Output
children.text: Data Policy Exception: Short description is mandatory

children.name: Example
children.text: // Setup a data policy where short_description field in incident is mandatory var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.insert(); // insert without data in mandatory field var errormessage = now_GR.getLastErrorMessage(); gs.info(errormessage);

children.name: String
children.text: The last error message as a string.

children.name: getLastErrorMessage()
children.text: Retrieves the last error message. If there is no last error message, null is returned.

children.name: String
children.text: Link to the current record.

children.name: noStack
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Flag indicating whether to append the sysparm_stack parameter to the returned link. This parameter specifies the page to visit after closing the current link.
Valid values:
  • true: Do not attach the sysparm_stack parameter.
  • false: Attach the sysparm_stack parameter.
If true, the sysparm_stack parameter is not appended to the link.

children.name: Output
children.text: https://instance.service-now.com/incident.do?sys_id=46e2fee9a9fe19810049b49dee0daf58&sysparm_stack=incident_list.do?sysparm_query=active=true

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addActiveQuery(); now_GR.addQuery("priority", 1); now_GR.query(); now_GR.next(); gs.info(gs.getProperty('glide.servlet.uri') + now_GR.getLink(false));
children.text2:
This  queries all Incident records with a priority of "1" and writes the servlet URI
        and the current record's link to the system log.

children.name: getLink(Boolean noStack)
children.text: Retrieves the link to the current record.

children.name: String
children.text: The class name.

children.name: Output
children.text: incident

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); var recordClassName = now_GR.getRecordClassName(); gs.info(recordClassName);

children.name: getRecordClassName()
children.text: Retrieves the class name for the current record.

children.name: Number
children.text: Number of rows.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.query(); gs.info("Records in incident table: " + now_GR.getRowCount());

children.name: getRowCount()
children.text: Retrieves the number of rows in the query result.

children.name: String
children.text: The table name

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); gs.info(now_GR.getTableName());

children.name: getTableName()
children.text: Retrieves the name of the table associated with the GlideRecord.

children.name: String
children.text: The unique primary key as a String, or null if the key is null.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('kb_knowledge'); now_GR.query(); now_GR.next(); var uniqueid = now_GR.getUniqueValue(); gs.info(uniqueid);

children.name: getUniqueValue()
children.text:
Gets the primary key of the record, which is usually the sys_id unless otherwise
    specified.

children.name: String
children.text:
The string value of the underlying element. Returns null if the field is empty
                or the field does not exist. Boolean values return as <kbd class="ph userinput">"0"</kbd> and
                  <kbd class="ph userinput">"1"</kbd> string values instead of false and true.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the field to get the value from.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.orderBy('number'); now_GR.query('active','true'); now_GR.next(); gs.info(now_GR.getValue('number'));

children.name: getValue(String name)
children.text: Retrieves the string value of an underlying element in a field.
children.text2: Note: If the Column Level Encryption Enterprise plugin is enabled and the instance has access to the key, this method returns clear text values from encrypted fields. If the instance does not have access to the key, this method returns the encrypted value. For more information, see Platform Encryption.

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if there are more records in the query result set.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.query(); if (rec.hasNext()) { gs.info("Table is not empty"); }

children.name: hasNext()
children.text: Determines if there are any more records in the GlideRecord object.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: Example
children.text: var grIncident = new GlideRecord('incident'); grIncident.initialize(); grIncident.setValue('short_description', 'New Incident'); grIncident.setValue('description', 'Incident description'); grIncident.insert();

children.name: initialize()
children.text: Creates an empty record suitable for population before an insert.

children.name: String
children.text: Sys_id of the inserted record, or null if the record is not inserted.

children.name: Output
children.text: 138fb4111b4d4d907cf30d03cd4bcb57

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.initialize(); now_GR.setValue('name', 'New Incident'); now_GR.setValue('description', 'Incident description'); now_GR.insert();

children.name: insert()
children.text: Inserts a new record using the field values that have been set for the current record.

children.name: Output
children.text: false

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); gs.info(now_GR.isActionAborted());

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates if the current database action is to be aborted.
Valid values:
  • true: The current database action is to be aborted.
  • false: The current database action is not to be aborted.

children.name: isActionAborted()
children.text: Checks to see if the current database action is to be aborted.
children.text2: isActionAborted() is initialized (set to false) for new threads and by the next() method.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the specified encoded query is valid.
  • true: Passed-in encoded query is valid
  • false: Passed-in encoded query is not valid

children.name: query
children.text: String
children.text2: Encoded query to validate. See Encoded query strings.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident_sla'); var isValidQuery = now_GR.isEncodedQueryValid('inc_impact=1^taskslatable_active=true'); if (isValidQuery) { now_GR.query(); . . . }
children.text2:
This code  shows how to validate an encoded query and then execute logic if the
        query is valid.

children.name: isEncodedQueryValid(String query)
children.text: Verifies whether the specified encoded query is valid.
children.text2: If the specified encoded query is valid, then the query is applied, just as if you had called addEncodedQuery(). If the specified encoded query is invalid, then sys_idNotValidnull is added as the encoded query.

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the record is new and has not been inserted into the database.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord("x_app_table"); now_GR.newRecord(); // create a new record and populate it with default values gs.info(now_GR.isNewRecord());

children.name: isNewRecord()
children.text:
Checks if the current record is a new record that has not yet been inserted into the
    database.

children.name: Example
children.text: var comment_GR = new GlideRecord('cf_comment'); var commentId = '99ebb4156fa831005be8883e6b3ee4b9'; comment_GR.get(commentId); gs.info(comment_GR.isValid());

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates if the table is valid or if the record was successfully retrieved.
Possible values:
  • true: Table is valid or the record was successfully retrieved.
  • false: Table is invalid or the record was not successfully retrieved.

children.name: isValid()
children.text:
Determines if the current table is valid or if the record was successfully
    retrieved.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.initialize(); gs.info(now_GR.isValidField("short_description"));

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the field is defined for the current table.

children.name: columnName
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the field.

children.name: isValidField(String columnName)
children.text: Determines if the specified field is defined in the current table.

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.query(); while (rec.next()) { gs.info(rec.number + ' exists'); } gs.info(rec.isValidRecord());

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether a record was actually returned by the query/get operation.
Valid values:
  • true: Record returned by query/get operation.
  • false: End of record set, no record returned.

children.name: isValidRecord()
children.text:
Determines if a record was actually returned by the query/get record
    operation.

children.name: Output
children.text: true

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord("x_app_table"); now_GR.newRecord(); gs.info(now_GR.isNewRecord());

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: newRecord()
children.text:
Creates a new GlideRecord record, sets the default values for the fields, and assigns a
    unique ID to the record.

children.name: Output
children.text:
INC0010112 exists
INC0010114 exists
INC0010119 exists
INC0010127 exists

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.query(); while (rec.next()) { gs.info(rec.getValue('number') + ' exists'); }

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates if there is a "next" record in the GlideRecord.
Valid values:
  • true: Move to the next record was successful.
  • false: No more records in the result set.

children.name: next()
children.text: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord object.
children.text2: Note: This method fails if there is a field in the table called "next". If that is the case, use the method _next().

children.name: Example
children.text: if(current.operation() == "update") { current.updates ++; } if(current.operation() == "insert") { current.updates = 0; }
children.text2: The following shows how to use this method in a business rule. The operation() method detects which operation triggered an event and performs a different action depending for update and insert operations.

children.name: String
children.text:
The current operation.
Possible values:
  • delete
  • insert
  • update

children.name: operation()
children.text: Determines if an operation is insert, update, or delete.
children.text2:
Knowing the operation enables using current.operation() to make a generic business rule which can handle each operation uniquely.

For information on using the global variable current, refer to Global variables in business rules.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Column name to use to order the records in this GlideRecord object.

children.name: Output
children.text:
Can't launch 64-bit Windows 7 virtual machine
Can't log into SAP from my laptop today
Network storage unavailable
Please remove the latest hotfix from my PC

children.name: Example
children.text: var queryString = "priority=2"; var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.orderBy('short_description'); // Ascending Order now_GR.addEncodedQuery(queryString); now_GR.query(); while (now_GR.next()) { gs.info(now_GR.getValue('short_description')); }
children.text2:
The following  shows how to order incident records in ascending order by Short
        Description.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: orderBy(String name)
children.text: Specifies an orderBy column.
children.text2: Call this method more than once to order by multiple columns. Results are arranged in ascending order. To arrange records in descending order, see Scoped GlideRecord - orderByDesc(String name).

children.name: Output
children.text:
Please remove the latest hotfix from my PC
Network storage unavailable
Can't log into SAP from my laptop today
Can't launch 64-bit Windows 7 virtual machine

children.name: Example
children.text: var queryString = "priority=2"; var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.orderByDesc('short_description'); //Descending Order now_GR.addEncodedQuery(queryString); now_GR.query(); while (now_GR.next()) { gs.info(now_GR.getValue('short_description')); }
children.text2:
The following  shows how to order incident records in descending order by Short
        Description.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Column name to use to order the records in a GlideRecord object.

children.name: orderByDesc(String name)
children.text: Specifies a descending orderBy column.
children.text2: Call this method more than once to order by multiple columns. Results are arranged in descending order. To arrange records in ascending order, see Scoped GlideRecord - orderBy(String name).

children.name: Output
children.text:
The following tables have a field column called "query":
cmdb_convert_bulk_services
cmdb_multisource_query_status
cmdb_qb_result_base
cmdb_qb_table_mapping
discovery_probes_cim_query
kb_feedback

children.name: Example
children.text: var tableArr = []; var now_GR = new GlideRecord('sys_dictionary'); now_GR.addQuery('element', 'query'); now_GR.setLimit(6); now_GR.query(); while(now_GR.next()){ tableArr.push(now_GR.name.getValue()); }; gs.info('The following tables have a field column called "query":'); for (i = 0; i < tableArr.length; i++) { gs.info(tableArr[i]); };
children.text2:
The following  shows how to scan the System Dictionary [sys_dictionary] for tables
        with a query field.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional - must also specify value parameter. Name of the field to search for the value specified in the value parameter.
Note: This method is typically run without arguments, but you can specify a name-value pair to filter records containing the specified values. If the parameters are specified, the "name=value" condition is added to the query.

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional - must also specify field parameter. Value to search for in the
                specified field parameter.

children.name: query(String field, String value)
children.text: Runs a query against the table based on the filters specified by query methods such as addQuery() and addEncodedQuery().
children.text2:
This method queries the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. For more information, see Querying tables in script.

Note: This method fails if there is a field in the table called "query". If that is the case, use the_query() method instead.

See the GlideRecord article for details on building and running queries.

See also:

  • GlideAggregate
  • GlideQuery
  • GlideQueryCondition

children.name: Example
children.text: // Often used in business rule to check whether the current operation should be aborted. if (current.size > 16) { current.setAbortAction(true); }

children.name: b
children.text: Boolean
children.text2: True to abort the next action. False if the action is to be allowed.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setAbortAction(Boolean b)
children.text:
Sets a flag to indicate if the next database action (insert, update, delete) is to be
    aborted. This is often used in business rules.
children.text2: Use in an onBefore business rule to prevent the database action from being done. The business rule continues to run after setAbortAction() is called. Calling setAbortAction() does not stop subsequent business rules from executing. Calling this method only prevents the database action from occurring.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.orderByDesc('sys_created_on'); now_GR.setLimit(10); now_GR.query(); // this retrieves latest 10 incident records created

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: maxNumRecords
children.text: Number
children.text2: The maximum number of records to fetch.

children.name: setLimit(Number maxNumRecords)
children.text: Sets the limit for number of records are fetched by the GlideRecord query.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: guid
children.text: String
children.text2: GUID to assign to the current record.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.setValue('short_description', 'The third floor printer is broken'); now_GR.setNewGuidValue('eb4636ca6f6d31005be8883e6b3ee333'); now_GR.insert(); gs.info(now_GR.getValue('sys_id'));

children.name: setNewGuidValue(String guid)
children.text: Sets the sys_id value for the current record.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the field.

children.name: Example
children.text: var elementName = 'short_description'; var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.initialize(); now_GR.setValue(elementName, "My DB is not working"); now_GR.insert();

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2: Value to assign to the field.

children.name: setValue(String name, Object value)
children.text: Sets the value of the field with the specified name to the specified value.
children.text2:
Normally the script does a now_GR.category = value. However, if the element name is itself a variable then you can use now_GR.setValue(elementName, value). When setting a value, ensure the data type of the field matches the data type of the value you enter.

Note: If the Column Level Encryption Enterprise plugin is enabled and the instance has access to the key, this method can insert encrypted data into encrypted fields. If the instance does not have access to the key, this method returns an error. For more information, see Platform Encryption.

children.name: enable
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
Flag that indicates whether to enable or disable the running of business rules, script engines, and audit.
Valid values:
  • true: Enable the running of business rules, script engines, and audit. (Default)
  • false: Disable the running of business rules, script engines, and audit.

children.name: Example
children.text: //Enable business rules, scripts engines for x_app_table var now_GR = new GlideRecord("x_app_table"); now_GR.setWorkflow(true);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: setWorkflow(Boolean enable)
children.text:
Enables or disables the running of business rules, script engines, and
    audit.
children.text2: Warning: Disabling the running of business rules, script engines, and audit can have a significant impact on your ServiceNow® instance and how it operates. Ensure that you thoroughly test this change before deploying it to production.

children.name: Output
children.text: Update the short description.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.get('99ebb4156fa831005be8883e6b3ee4b9'); now_GR.setValue('short_description', 'Update the short description'); now_GR.update(); gs.info(now_GR.getElement('short_description'));
children.text2: The following  shows how to update the Short Description field of an incident.

children.name: String
children.text: Sys_id of the new or updated record. Returns null if the update fails.

children.name: reason
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional. Reason for the update. The reason appears in the audit
                record.

children.name: update(String reason)
children.text:
Updates the GlideRecord with any changes that have been made. If the record does not
    already exist, it is inserted.

children.name: Example
children.text: var now_GR = new GlideRecord('incident'); now_GR.addQuery('active', true); now_GR.setValue('state', 4); now_GR.updateMultiple();
children.text2:
This  shows how to update the state of all active incidents to 4 - "Awaiting User
        Info".

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: updateMultiple()
children.text: Updates each GlideRecord in a stated query with a specified set of changes.
children.text2:
This method does not support adding multiple journal entries.

Note: To ensure expected results, use the setValue() method instead of direct assignments. That is, use gr.setValue('<field_name>', '4')); instead of gr.<field_name> = 4.

Note: Do not use this method with the chooseWindow() or setLimit() methods when working with large tables.

This method sets new values and does not clear existing values. To clear an existing value, use the setValue() method and set the field to null.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether there are more records in the query set.
Possible values:
  • true: More records in the query set.
  • false: No more records in the query set.

children.name: Output
children.text:
INC0000060 exists
INC0009002 exists
INC0000009 exists
INC0000010 exists
INC0000011 exists
INC0000012 exists
...

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('incident'); rec.query(); while (rec._next()) { gs.info(rec.getValue('number') + ' exists'); }
children.text2: The following  shows how to list each record in the Incidents [incident] table.

children.name: _next()
children.text: Moves to the next record in the GlideRecord. Provides the same functionality as next(), use this method if the GlideRecord has a column named next.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional - must also specify value parameter. Name of the field to search for the value specified in the value parameter.
Note: This method is typically run without arguments, but you can specify a name-value pair to filter records containing the specified values. If the parameters are specified, the "name=value" condition is added to the query.

children.name: Output
children.text:
KB0000005 comment: 
	     Can you please add the version of Excel this applies to? All?
		
KB0000005 comment: 
	     Does this work for all Excel versions? OSX and Windows alike?

children.name: Example
children.text: var rec = new GlideRecord('kb_feedback'); rec.addQuery('comments', 'CONTAINS', 'Excel'); rec._query(); while (rec.next()) { gs.info(rec.getDisplayValue('article') + " comment: " + rec.getValue('comments')); }
children.text2:
The following  shows how query the Knowledge Feedback [kb_feedback] table and list
        KB articles with comments that include Excel.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: value
children.text: String
children.text2:
Optional - must also specify field parameter. Value to search for in the
                specified field parameter.

children.name: _query(String field, String value)
children.text: Runs a query against the table based on the filters specified by query methods such as addQuery() and addEncodedQuery(). This method is intended to be used on tables in which there is a column named "query", which might cause errors running the query() method.
children.text2:
This method queries the GlideRecord table as well as any references of the table. For more information, see Querying tables in script.

See the GlideRecord article for details on building and running queries.

See also:

  • GlideAggregate
  • GlideQuery
  • GlideQueryCondition

name: GlideRecord
text: Scoped GlideRecord is used for database operations.
text2:
The GlideRecord API is the primary means of interfacing with the database on the server-side code. A GlideRecord is an object that contains records from a single table. Use the API to instantiate a GlideRecord object and add query parameters, filters, limits, and ordering.

See the GlideRecord article for details on building and running queries.

For information on a class that performs the same functions as GlideRecord and enforces ACLs, see Using GlideRecordSecure.

Always test queries on a sub-production instance prior to deploying them on a production instance. An incorrectly constructed encoded query, such as including an invalid field name, produces an invalid query. When the invalid query is run, the invalid part of the query condition is dropped, and the results are based on the valid part of the query, which may return all records from the table. Using an insert(), update(), deleteRecord(), or deleteMultiple() method on bad query results can result in data loss.

You can set the glide.invalid_query.returns_no_rows system property to true to have queries with invalid encoded queries return no records.



Retrieve values from records

In most cases, do not use dot-walking to get values from a record. Dot-walking retrieves the entire object instead of the field value. Retrieving the object uses much more storage and might cause undesirable results when used in arrays or in Service Portal.

Instead of retrieving the entire object, you can use one of the following methods to copy the field values:

  • getValue()
  • getDisplayValue()
If dot-walking through a GlideElement object is necessary, use the toString() method to retrieve values. For example, you might need the current caller's manager sys_id to set another reference field. The following example shows how to get the string value instead of the entire object:
var mgr = current.caller_id.manager.toString();


See also:
  • GlideAggregate
  • GlideElement
  • GlideQuery

children.name: GlideSchedule()
children.text: Instantiates an empty GlideSchedule object.

children.name: Example
children.text: var schedule = new GlideSchedule('090eecae0a0a0b260077e1dfa71da828', 'US/Pacific');

children.name: sysID
children.text: String
children.text2: The system ID for the schedule.

children.name: timeZone
children.text: String
children.text2: The time zone. (Optional)

children.name: GlideSchedule(String sysID, String timeZone)
children.text:
Instantiates a GlideSchedule object and loads the schedule information. If a timezone
    is not specified or is nil, the current session timezone is used.

children.name: startDate
children.text: GlideDateTime
children.text2: The starting date of the new schedule segment.

children.name: Example
children.text: var startDate = new GlideDateTime('2014-01-02'); var days = 2; var dur = new GlideDuration(60 * 60 * 24 * 1000 * days); var schedule = new GlideSchedule(); var end = schedule.add(startDate, dur); gs.info(end);

children.name: GlideDateTime
children.text: The schedule updated with the new schedule segment.

children.name: offSet
children.text: GlideDuration
children.text2: The time offset of the new schedule segment.

children.name: add(GlideDateTime startDate, GlideDuration offSet)
children.text: Adds a new schedule segment to the current schedule.

children.name: startDate
children.text: GlideDateTime
children.text2: The starting datetime.

children.name: Example
children.text: var startDate = new GlideDateTime('2014-10-16 02:00:00'); var endDate = new GlideDateTime('2014-10-18 04:00:00'); var schedule = new GlideSchedule(); schedule.load('090eecae0a0a0b260077e1dfa71da828'); // loads "8-5 weekdays excluding holidays" schedule var duration = schedule.duration(startDate, endDate); gs.info(duration.getDurationValue()); // gets the elapsed time in schedule

children.name: GlideDuration
children.text: The difference between the starting and ending datetime.

children.name: endDate
children.text: GlideDateTime
children.text2: The ending datetime.

children.name: duration(GlideDateTime startDate, GlideDateTime endDate)
children.text:
Determines the elapsed time in the schedule between two date time values using the
    timezone of the schedule or, if that is not specified, the timezone of the session.

children.name: Example
children.text: sys_id ='04e664654a36232701a2247dcd8fc4cf'; // sys_id for "Application" schedule record var sched = new GlideSchedule(sys_id); gs.info(sched.getName());

children.name: String
children.text: The name of the current schedule.

children.name: getName()
children.text: Retrieves the schedule name.

children.name: Example
children.text: var glide = new GlideRecord('cmn_schedule'); glide.addQuery('type', 'blackout'); glide.query(); if (glide.next()) { var sched = new GlideSchedule(glide.sys_id); var date = new GlideDateTime(); date.setDisplayValue("2007-09-18 12:00:00"); if (sched.isInSchedule(date)) gs.info("Is in the schedule"); else gs.info("Is NOT in the schedule"); }

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the specified date and time is within the schedule.
Valid values:
  • true: Date and time is within the schedule.
  • false: Date and time are outside of the schedule.

children.name: time
children.text: GlideDateTime
children.text2: Date and time value to check.

children.name: isInSchedule(GlideDateTime time)
children.text: Determines if the specified date and time is within the current schedule.

children.name: Example
children.text: var glide = new GlideRecord('cmn_schedule'); glide.addQuery('type', 'blackout'); glide.query(); if (glide.next()) { var sched = new GlideSchedule(glide.sys_id); var date = new GlideDateTime(); date.setDisplayValue("2007-09-18 12:00:00"); if (sched.isValid()) gs.info("Is valid"); else gs.info("Is not valid"); }

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the schedule is valid.

children.name: isValid()
children.text:
Determines if the current schedule is valid. A schedule is valid if it has at least one
    schedule span.

children.name: Example
children.text: var x = new GlideSchedule(); x.load('08fcd0830a0a0b2600079f56b1adb9ae');

children.name: sysID
children.text: String
children.text2: The system ID of the schedule.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeZone
children.text: String
children.text2:
(Optional) The timezone. If a timezone is not specified, or is nil, the current
                session timezone is used for the schedule.

children.name: excludeSpanID
children.text: String
children.text2: Any span to exclude.

children.name: load(String sysID, String timeZone, String excludeSpanID)
children.text: Loads a schedule with the schedule information.

children.name: Example
children.text: var schedule = new GlideSchedule(); schedule.setTimeZone('US/Pacific');
children.text2: This  sets the timezone for the schedule to US/Pacific.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: timeZone
children.text: String
children.text2: The timezone.

children.name: setTimeZone(String timeZone)
children.text: Sets the timezone for the current schedule.

children.name: time
children.text: GlideDateTime
children.text2: Time to be evaluated

children.name: Example
children.text: var startDate = new GlideDateTime('2014-10-25 08:00:00'); var glideSchedule = new GlideSchedule('08fcd0830a0a0b2600079f56b1adb9ae', 'UTC'); gs.info(glideSchedule.whenNext(startDate));

children.name: Number
children.text:
Number of milliseconds until the start time of the next schedule item. Returns
                -1 if never.

children.name: timeZone
children.text: String
children.text2: Timezone

children.name: Output
children.text2:
[Scheduled for future] *** Script: Not currently in schedule *** Script: Next schedule
        starts in 332894000 milliseconds

children.name: Example
children.text: testScript(); function testScript() { var now = new GlideDateTime(); //current date and time var sched = new GlideSchedule("<sys_id>"); // Use a cmn_schedule sys_id if (sched.isInSchedule(now)){ gs.info('We are in an active schedule window so whenNext() is not helpful'); } else{ gs.info('Not currently in schedule so call whenNext()'); var msUntilNext = sched.whenNext(new GlideDateTime(), 'US/Pacific'); gs.info('Next schedule starts in '+msUntilNext+' milliseconds'); } } \\ Output [schedule inactive)]: \\ *** Script: Not currently in schedule so call whenNext() \\ *** Script: Next schedule starts in -1 milliseconds

children.name: whenNext(GlideDateTime time, String timeZone)
children.text:
Determines how much time (in milliseconds) until start time of the next schedule
    item.
children.text2: This function is intended to be called when the GlideSchedule object (cmn_schedule table) is not currently in the schedule window. The whenNext() call returns duration (in ms) until the GlideSchedule object is within the schedule. This function does not return a meaningful value if called when the GlideSchedule object is within the schedule.

name: GlideSchedule
text: The scoped GlideSchedule API provides methods for performing operations on GlideSchedule objects, such as adding new schedule segments to a schedule, determining if a datetime is within the schedule, or setting the schedule timezone.

children.name: GlideScopedEvaluator()
children.text: Instantiates a GlideScopedEvaluator object.

children.name: grObj
children.text: GlideRecord
children.text2: The GlideRecord containing a script expression.

children.name: Output
children.text2: admin says hello

children.name: Example
children.text: //For this example, we created a table: "x_app_table" with two columns: "short_description", "test_script" // "test_script" will store the script to be evaluated by GlideScopedEvaluator. var now_GR = new GlideRecord('x_app_table'); now_GR.short_description = 'Testing GlideScopedEvaluator'; now_GR.test_script = "gs.getUser().getName() + ' says ' + greeting; "; now_GR.insert(); //setup variables to be used by the script var vars = {'greeting' : 'hello'}; //Evaluate the script from the field var evaluator = new GlideScopedEvaluator(); gs.info(evaluator.evaluateScript(now_GR, 'test_script', vars)); // Now retrieve the result evaluator.evaluateScript(gr, 'u_test_script', null); gs.info(evaluator.getVariable('result'));

children.name: Object
children.text: The result of the script execution.

children.name: scriptField
children.text: String
children.text2: (Optional) The name of the field containing the script expression.

children.name: variables
children.text: Object
children.text2:
(Optional) A map of variables with name-value pairs. These variables are
                available to the script during execution of this method.

children.name: evaluateScript(GlideRecord grObj, String scriptField, Object variables)
children.text: Evaluates a script from a GlideRecord field.

children.name: Example
children.text: //setting up a record that contains the script to be executed. var now_GR = new GlideRecord('u_global_table'); now_GR.u_short_description = 'Calculate Addition'; now_GR.u_test_script = "result = x + y"; now_GR.insert(); var evaluator = new GlideScopedEvaluator(); evaluator.putVariable('x', 100); evaluator.putVariable('y', 200); evaluator.putVariable('result', null);

children.name: Object
children.text: The value of the specified variable.

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the variable.

children.name: getVariable(String name)
children.text: Returns a variable from a GlideScopedEvaluator object.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: name
children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the variable.

children.name: Example
children.text: //setting up a record that contains the script to be executed. var now_GR = new GlideRecord('u_global_table'); now_GR.u_short_description = 'Calculate Addition'; now_GR.u_test_script = "result = x + y"; now_GR.insert(); var evaluator = new GlideScopedEvaluator(); evaluator.putVariable('x', 100); evaluator.putVariable('y', 200); evaluator.putVariable('result', null);

children.name: value
children.text: Object
children.text2: The value of the variable.

children.name: putVariable(String name, Object value)
children.text:
Puts a variable into the GlideScopedEvaluator object. These variables are available to
    the script that this GlideScopedEvaluator object runs.

name: GlideScopedEvaluator
text:
The GlideScopedEvaluator API allows you to evaluate scripts in a GlideRecord field from
  both scoped and global server scripts.
text2:
The GlideScopedEvaluator API evaluates records with script fields defined. The scope of the
   script is defined by the scope of the record.

name: GlideScriptableInputStream
text: A GlideScriptableInputStream object cannot be instantiated directly, but is used as an opaque object which is used to connect an input stream from GlideSysAttachment.getContentStream() with other streaming APIs, such as GlideTextReader, GlideDigest, and XMLDocument2.
text2:
See the scoped GlideSysAttachment API for methods that return a GlideScriptableInputStream
   object. The scoped GlideTextReader constructor requires a GlideScriptableInputStream object as an
   input parameter.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: url
children.text: String
children.text2: Destination URL

children.name: Example
children.text: //Do whatever processing you need and redirect to the homepage g_processor.redirect("/navpage.do")

children.name: redirect(String url)
children.text: Redirects to the specified URL.

children.name: o
children.text: Object
children.text2: The object to encode to a JSON string.

children.name: Example
children.text: var map = {"key1":"value1","key2":"value2"}; g_processor.writeJSON(map);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: writeJSON(Object o)
children.text: Encodes an object as a JSON string and writes it to the current URL.

children.name: contentType
children.text: String
children.text2:
Sets the content type of the response sent to the client, if the response has
                not been committed, and may include a character-encoding specification.

children.name: Example
children.text: var name = g_request.getParameter("name"); g_processor.writeOutput("text/plain", "Hello " + name);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: s
children.text: String
children.text2: The string to write.

children.name: writeOutput(String contentType, String s)
children.text:
Writes the specified string to the current URL in the specified
    character-encoding.

children.name: Example
children.text: var name = g_request.getParameter("name"); g_processor.writeOutput("Hello " + name);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: s
children.text: String
children.text2: The string to write.

children.name: writeOutput(String s)
children.text: Writes the specified string to the current URL.

name: GlideScriptedProcessor
text: ServiceNow processors are equivalent to Java servlets.
text2:
Processors provide a customizable URL endpoint that can execute arbitrary server-side JavaScript code and produce output such as TEXT, JSON, or HTML. The ScopedGlideScriptedProcessor APIs are used in processor scripts to access the the processor (servlet) capabilities. There are no constructors for the ScopedGlideScriptedProcessor APIs. The methods are called using the global variable g_processor.

A useful global variable, g_target, is available in processor scripts. It contains the table name extracted from the URL.

The URL to a processor has the format: https://<instance name.servicenow.com>/<path endpoint>.do?<parameter endpoint>=<value> where the path endpoint and parameter endpoint are defined on the processor form.

children.name: Example
children.text: gs.info(GlideSecureRandomUtil.getSecureRandomInt());

children.name: Number

children.name: Example

Generates a pseudo-random integer between 0 (inclusive) and the bound (exclusive) value
    that you pass into the method.

children.text: Generates a random alpha-numeric String with the specified length.

name: GlideSecureRandomUtil
text:
The scoped GlideSecureRandomUtil API provides methods for generating integers, long
  values, and strings.
text2:
There is no constructor for this class. Methods are accessed through the static object
   GlideSecureRandomUtil. The GlideSecureRandomUtil class is available in both global and scoped
   applications.

children.name: url
children.text: String
children.text2: The URL to be checked.

children.name: Output
children.text2: null

children.name: Example
children.text: myurl='javascript%3Aalert(1)'; var clean=GlideSecurityUtils.cleanURL(myurl); gs.info(clean);

children.name: String
children.text: The URL stripped of problem elements.

children.name: cleanURL(String url)
children.text:
Removes suspicious encoding to prevent reflected or DOM based cross site
    scripting.

children.name: Output
children.text2: test.do

children.name: Example

children.text: A relative URL.

children.name: url

children.text2: The URL to be turned into a relative URL.

children.name: enforceRelativeURL(String url)
children.text:
Removes the domain address from the URL, which leaves the page name and
    parameters.

children.name: String
children.text: The script with escape characters added.

children.name: script
children.text: String
children.text2: The script to have escape characters added.

children.name: Output
children.text2: <script> alert(1)</script>

children.name: Example
children.text: theScript="<script> alert(1)</script>"; var escapedScript=GlideSecurityUtils.escapeScript(theScript); gs.info(escapedScript);

children.name: escapeScript(String script)
children.text: Add escape characters to a script.
children.text2: Adding escape characters to a script helps prevent cross-site scripting.

children.name: Output
children.text2: false

children.name: Example
children.text: myURL="http://evil.com/badscript.do"; isWhitelisted=GlideSecurityUtils.isURLWhiteListed(myURL); gs.info(isWhitelisted);

children.name: Boolean
children.text: Returns true if the specified URL is in the allow list.

children.name: url
children.text: String
children.text2: The URL to be checked against the URL allow list.

children.name: isURLWhiteListed(String url)
children.text: Check the specified URL against the system defined allow list.

name: GlideSecurityUtils- Scoped, Global
text: Provides methods to work with URLs.

The name of the parameter to be retrieved. This can be the parameter endpoint

name: GlideServletRequest
text: The GlideServletRequest API is used in processor scripts.
text2:
ServiceNow processors are equivalent to Java servlets. Processors provide a customizable URL endpoint that can execute arbitrary server-side JavaScript code and produce output such as TEXT, JSON, or HTML. The GlideServletRequest API is used in processor scripts to access the HttpServletRequest object. The GlideServletRequest object provides a subset of the HttpServletRequest APIs. The methods are called using the global variable g_request.

A useful global variable, g_target, is available in processor scripts. It contains the table name extracted from the URL.

The URL to a processor has the format: https://<instance name.servicenow.com>/<path endpoint>.do?<parameter endpoint>=<value> where the path endpoint and parameter endpoint are defined on the processor form.

children.name: location
children.text: String
children.text2: The URL to receive the response.

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: sendRedirect(String location)
children.text: Sends a temporary redirect to the client.

children.text: Method does not return a value

children.text: Sets the MIME type of the response

The value to be assigned to the header. If the header exists, it is

children.name: setStatus(Number status)
children.text: Sets the status code for the response.

name: GlideServletResponse
text: The ScopedGlideServletResponse API is used in processor scripts.
text2:
ServiceNow processors are equivalent to Java servlets. Processors provide a customizable URL endpoint that can execute arbitrary server-side JavaScript code and produce output such as TEXT, JSON, or HTML. The ScopedGlideServletResponse API is used in processor scripts to access the HttpServletResponse object. The ScopedGlideServletResponse object provides a subset of the HttpServletResponse APIs. The methods are called using the global variable g_response.

A useful global variable, g_target, is available in processor scripts. It contains the table name extracted from the URL.

The URL to a processor has the format: https://<instance name.servicenow.com>/<path endpoint>.do?<parameter endpoint>=<value> where the path endpoint and parameter endpoint are defined on the processor form.

children.name: paramName
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the client data to retrieve.

children.name: Output
children.text: Harry

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); session.putClientData('test1', 'Harry'); var clientData = session.getClientData('test1'); gs.info(clientData);

children.name: String
children.text: The client data as a string.

children.name: getClientData(String paramName)
children.text: Retrieves a session client value previously set with putClientData().
children.text2: Use this method to retrieve data values that were set using the putClientData() method.

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var addr = session.getClientIP(); gs.info(addr);

children.name: String
children.text: The IP address.

children.name: getClientIP()
children.text: Returns the client IP address.

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var appID = session.getCurrentApplicationId(); gs.info(appID);

children.name: String
children.text: The currently selected application.

children.name: getCurrentApplicationId()
children.text: Returns the application currently selected in the application picker.
children.text2: This method requires admin privileges.

children.name: Example
children.text: // Set domain based on parent record's domain setDomain(); // If the domain is global, set to user's domain if (current.sys_domain == 'global' || current.sys_domain.nil()) current.sys_domain = gs.getSession().getCurrentDomainID(); function setDomain() { if (current.target_table.nil()) return; var d = new GlideRecord(current.target_table); if (!d.isValid()) return; if (!d.get('sys_id', current.instance)) return; if (typeof(d.sys_domain) == 'object') current.sys_domain = d.sys_domain;
children.text2:
This  shows the current sys_email record’s domain being set to the user’s session
        domain, if the user domain is global or null.

children.name: String
children.text:
Sys_id of the session domain of the current logged-in user. This is the same
                information that appears in the domain picker.

children.name: getCurrentDomainID()
children.text: Returns the sys_id of the current domain for the logged-in user session.
children.text2:
The identifier that is returned depends on the domain type and the instantiation of that domain.

  • If the user is configured in the global domain, and does not use the domain picker to switch domains, the method returns null.
  • If the user uses the domain picker to switch to the global domain, the method returns the string "global".
  • For all other domains, the method returns the sys_id of that domain.

children.name: Output
children.text: en

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var language = session.getLanguage(); gs.info(language);

children.name: String
children.text: The session's language code.

children.name: getLanguage()
children.text: Returns the session's language code.

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var token = session.getSessionToken(); gs.info(token);

children.name: String
children.text: The session token.

children.name: getSessionToken()
children.text: Returns the session token.

children.name: Output
children.text: US/Pacific

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var zoneName = session.getTimeZoneName(); gs.info(zoneName);

children.name: String
children.text: The name of the session's time zone.

children.name: getTimeZoneName()
children.text: Returns the name of the session's time zone.

children.name: Output
children.text:
sys_app.do?sys_id=ce05b9f32b840200c5244f74b4da1501&sysparm_goto_url=sys_app.do
%3Fsys_id%3Dce05b9f32b840200c5244f74b4da1501
children.text2: line breaks added for clarity.

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var URL = session.getUrlOnStack(); gs.info(URL);

children.name: String
children.text: The URL. Returns null if the stack is empty.

children.name: getUrlOnStack()
children.text: Returns the URL on the stack. Returns null if the stack is empty.

children.name: Example
children.text: var isImpersonator = gs.getSession().isImpersonating(); gs.info(isImpersonator);

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Returns true if the user is impersonating another user; otherwise, returns
                false.

children.name: isImpersonating()
children.text: Returns true if the user is impersonating another user.

children.name: Example
children.text: var interActive = gs.getSession().isInteractive(); gs.info(interActive);

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the session is interactive.

children.name: isInteractive()
children.text: Returns true if the session is interactive.
children.text2: An interactive session is one that involves an end-user interacting with a user interface that then retrieves information from a server. An example of this type of session is when a user logs in using the log-in screen or uses a form to query a data store. A non-interactive session is one that only involves programmatic interaction with a server such as a SOAP request to retrieve data.

children.name: Output
children.text: true

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); var loggedIn = session.isLoggedIn(); gs.info(loggedIn);

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the user is logged in.

children.name: isLoggedIn()
children.text: Returns true if the user is logged in.

children.name: Output
children.text: Harry

children.name: Example
children.text: var session = gs.getSession(); session.putClientData('test1', 'Harry'); var clientData = session.getClientData('test1'); gs.info(clientData);

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: paramName
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the client data to set.

children.name: paramValue
children.text: String
children.text2: Value of the client data.

children.name: putClientData(String paramName, String paramValue)
children.text: Sets a session client value that can be retrieved with getClientData(). This method is used in a server side script that runs when a form is created.

name: GlideSession
text: The scoped GlideSession API provides a way to find information about the current session.
text2: There are no constructors for creating an instance of a scoped GlideSession object. Instead, use the getSession() method of the scoped GlideSystem API.

children.name: Example
children.text: //Server script data.items = []; data.userName = gs.getUserDisplayName(); var now_GR = new GlideRecord("sc_cat_item"); now_GR.query(); while(now_GR.next() && data.items.length < 10) { if ($sp.canReadRecord(now_GR)) { data.items.push(now_GR.getDisplayValue("name")); } } //HTML template <div class="panel panel-default"> <div class="panel-heading">Hi, {{c.data.userName}}!</div> <div class="panel-body"> Here are some things you can order: <ul><li ng-repeat="item in c.data.items">{{item}}</li></ul> </div> </div>
children.text2: Server script

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the record is valid and readable.

children.name: now_GR
children.text: GlideRecord
children.text2: The GlideRecord to check.

children.name: canReadRecord(GlideRecord now_GR)
children.text: Returns true if the user can read the specified GlideRecord.
children.text2: If the record type is kb_knowledge, sc_cat_item, or sc_category, the method checks if the user can view the item.

children.name: table
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the table to query.

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the record is valid and readable.

children.name: sysId
children.text: String
children.text2: Sys_id of the record to query.

children.name: canReadRecord(String table, String sysId)
children.text: Returns true if the user can read the specified GlideRecord.
children.text2: If the record type is kb_knowledge, sc_cat_item, or sc_category, the method checks if the user can view the item.

children.name: pageID
children.text: String
children.text2: Page ID from the Pages [sp_page] table.

children.name: Example
children.text: GlideSPScriptable.canSeePage("kb_view2")
children.text2:
This  adds a condition to the Knowledge menu item in the SP Header Menu to only show
        the menu item to users who have permission to view the kb_view2 page.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the currently logged in user has permissions to view the specified page. Values include:
  • true: The user can view the page.
  • false: Either the user cannot view the page, the given pageID is not valid, or the user is not logged in.

children.name: canSeePage(String pageID)
children.text:
Returns true if the currently logged in user has permission to view the specified
    page.
children.text2: The system determines permission using roles and user criteria. For more information, see Configure page security by role and User criteria for Service Portal.

children.name: Example
children.text: // Server script (function() { var sys_id = $sp.getParameter("sys_id") data.catItem = $sp.getCatalogItem(sys_id); })(); // Client script function($http, spUtil) { var c = this; var submitting = false; c.getIt = function() { if (submitting) return; $http.post(spUtil.getURL('sc_cat_item'), c.data.catItem).success(function(response) { if (response.answer) { c.req = response.answer; c.req.page = c.req.table == 'sc_request' ? 'sc_request' : 'ticket'; } }); } } //SCSS .img-bg { padding: 5px; background-color: $brand-primary; } .img-responsive { margin: 0 auto; } .cat-icon { display: block; margin: -40px auto 0; } // HTML template <div class="col-sm-4"> <div class="panel panel-default"> <div class="img-bg"> <img ng-src="{{::data.catItem.picture}}" class="img-responsive" /> </div> <span class="cat-icon fa fa-stack fa-lg fa-3x hidden-xs"> <i class="fa fa-circle fa-stack-2x text-success"></i> <i class="fa fa-desktop fa-stack-1x fa-inverse"></i> </span> <div class="panel-body"> <p class="lead text-center">{{::data.catItem.name}}</p> <ul class="list-unstyled"> <li class="text-center" ng-if="::data.catItem.price">${Price}: {{::data.catItem.price}}</li> </ul> <sp-model form-model="::data.catItem" mandatory="mandatory"></sp-model> <p ng-if="c.req" class="text-center text-success"> ${Request created!} <a href="?id={{c.req.page}}&table={{c.req.table}}&sys_id={{c.req.sys_id}}">{{c.req.number}}</a> </p> <button ng-if="!c.req" class="btn btn-default btn-block" ng-click="c.getIt()">${Get it}</button> </div> </div> </div>

children.name: Object
children.text:
An object containing the catalog item variable model, view, sections, pricing,
                and client scripts.

children.name: sysId
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_id of the catalog item (sc_cat_item) or order guide (sc_cat_item_guide).

children.name: getCatalogItem(String sysId)
children.text: Returns a model and view model for a sc_cat_item or sc_cat_item_guide.
children.text2:
This method is deprecated. Use the getCatalogItem(String sysId, Boolean isOrdering) method instead. This method calls the getCatalogItem(String sysId, Boolean isOrdering) method with the isOrdering parameter set to false, which means that write roles security checking is done.

This method is a quick way to get the data necessary to render and order a catalog item using <sp-model />. If you just need to get a catalog item to show its picture or name, use GlideRecord to query the sc_cat_item table.

children.name: sysId
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_id of the catalog item (sc_cat_item) or order guide (sc_cat_item_guide).

children.name: Object
children.text:
An object containing the catalog item variable model, view, sections, pricing,
                and client scripts.

children.name: isOrdering
children.text: Boolean
children.text2:
When true, uses create roles security check. When false, uses write roles security check.

When users are ordering an item or have it in their cart, check using the create roles.

If users are not ordering, for example, somebody is looking at a requested item to see the variables associated with that item, then check using the write roles.

children.name: getCatalogItem(String sysId, Boolean isOrdering)
children.text: Returns a model and view model for a sc_cat_item or sc_cat_item_guide.

The articles within the category and its subcategories with:
  • A workflow_state of published.
  • A valid_to date greater than or equal to the current date.

children.text: //Server script (function() { data.kbs = $sp.getKBCategoryArticles("0ac1bf8bff0221009b20ffffffffffec", 5); })(); //HTML template <div> articles: {{::data.kbs}} </div>

children.name: getKBCategoryArticles(String sys_id, Number limit)
children.text: Returns KB articles in the specified category and its subcategories.
children.text2: To avoid performance issues, do not use this method to return articles in large categories or articles with inline images. Instead, use getKBArticleSummaries().

children.name: Array
children.text:
The articles within the category and its subcategories with:
  • A workflow_state of published.
  • A valid_to date greater than or equal to the current date.

children.name: Example
children.text: //Server script (function() { var portalGr = $sp.getPortalRecord(); data.logo = portalGr.getDisplayValue("logo"); data.homepage = portalGr.getDisplayValue("homepage.id"); })(); //HTML template <div> <img ng-src="{{::c.data.logo}}" /> <a href="?id={{::c.data.homepage}}">Click here to go home</a> </div>
