name: RenderProperties
text:
The RenderProperties API provides methods about the current page and is available in
  Jelly scripts and in UI-action conditions and scripts.
text2: Access RenderProperties methods using the static variable RP.

children.name: dictEntries
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_ids of the records you want to classify. The sys_ids are from the Dictionary [sys_dictionary] table. Entered as a comma-separated list enclosed in a string.

children.name: Output
children.text: "Successfully stored the data classification configurations"

children.name: Example
children.text: var dcm = new global.ScopedDCManager(); var confidentialClass = {}; var ssnFields = []; var dataClasses = JSON.parse(dcm.getAllDataClasses()); // Get the Confidential data class record dataClasses.forEach(function (dataClass) { if (dataClass.name == "Confidential") confidentialClass = dataClass; }); // Find the fields that seem to be strong social security numbers var dictionaryGR = new GlideRecord("sys_dictionary"); dictionaryGR.addQuery("element", "ssn").addOrCondition("element", "social_security_number"); dictionaryGR.query(); while (dictionaryGR.next()) ssnFields.push(dictionaryGR.getUniqueValue()); // Classify any found entries as confidential if (ssnFields.length > 0) dcm.classify(ssnFields.join(), confidentialClass.sys_id);
children.text2: This finds records containing social security numbers and classifies the records as confidential.

children.name: String
children.text: Message describing the result of the operation.

children.name: dataClasses
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_ids of the data classifications you want to assign. The sys_ids are from the Data Classification [data_classification] table. Entered as a comma-separated list enclosed in a string.

children.name: classify(String dictEntries, String dataClasses)
children.text: Assigns pre-defined or user-defined data classifications to existing dictionary entries.
children.text2: Requires the admin or data_classification_admin role.

children.name: Output
children.text: "Classifications removed for the specified dictionary entries"

children.name: Example
children.text: var dcm = new global.ScopedDCManager(); gs.info(dcm.clearClassification(“445de0a6dba30300efc57416bf9619b0”));
children.text2: This  removes the data classification for a dictionary entry.

children.name: String
children.text: Message describing the result of the operation.

children.name: dictEntries
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_ids of the records you want to remove classifications from. The sys_ids are from the Dictionary [sys_dictionary] table. Entered as a comma-separated list enclosed in a string.

children.name: clearClassification(String dictEntries)
children.text: Removes all data classifications for the specified dictionary entries.
children.text2: Requires the admin or data_classification_admin role.

children.name: <Array>
children.text:
Result of the request. Returns the sys_id and name for each available data classification. If there are no data classifications, it returns an empty array.

Data classifications can be organized into parent-child relationships. If there are parent data classifications, they are identified in the result.

Data type: Array

[
  {
    "parent": {Object},
    "sys_id": "String",
    "name": "String"
  }
]

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var dcm = new global.ScopedDCManager(); gs.info(dcm.getAllDataClasses());
children.text2: This  retrieves a list of all available data classifications.

children.name: <Array>.parent
<Array>.parent.sys_id
children.text:
Sys_id of the parent data classification from the Data Classification [data_classification] table.

Data type: String

children.name: <Array>.parent.name
children.text:
Name of the parent data classification.

Data type: String

children.name: <Array>.sys_id
children.text:
Sys_id of the data classification from the Data Classification [data_classification] table.

Data type: String

children.name: <Array>.name
children.text:
Name of the data classification.

Data type: String

children.name: getAllDataClasses()
children.text: Returns a list of all data classifications available in the current domain.
children.text2: Requires the admin, data_classification_admin, or data_classification_auditor role.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var dcm = new global.ScopedDCManager(); gs.info(dcm.getClassification(“445de0a6dba30300efc57416bf9619b0”));
children.text2: This  retrieves the data classifications for a dictionary entry.

children.name: <Object>
children.text:
JSON object containing each dictionary entry's sys_id with an array of its associated data classes. If there are no associated data classifications, it returns a message describing the result of the operation.

Data classifications can be organized into parent-child relationships. If there are parent data classifications, they are identified in the result.

Data type: Object

{
  <sys_dictionary_sys_id>: [
    {
      "parent": {Object},
      "sys_id": "String",
      "name": "String"
    }
  ]
}

children.name: dictEntries
children.text: String
children.text2: The sys_ids of the records you want to retrieve classifications for. The sys_ids are from the Dictionary [sys_dictionary] table. Entered as a comma-separated list enclosed in a string.

children.name: <Object>.parent
<Object>.parent.sys_id
children.text:
Sys_id of the parent data classification from the Data Classification [data_classification] table.

Data type: String

children.name: <Object>.parent.name
children.text:
Name of the parent data classification.

Data type: String

children.name: <Object>.sys_id
children.text:
Sys_id of the data classification from the Data Classification [data_classification] table.

Data type: String

children.name: <Object>.name
children.text:
Name of the data classification.

Data type: String

children.name: getClassification(String dictEntries)
children.text: Retrieves all data classifications for the specified dictionary entries.
children.text2: Requires the admin, data_classification_admin, or data_classification_auditor role.

name: ScopedDCManager
text: The ScopedDCManager API enables you to group data by type.
text2:
With the ScopedDCManager API, you can:
  • Assign data classifications to existing dictionary entries.
  • Look up the data classifications for specific dictionary entries.
  • Remove all data classifications associated with specific dictionary entries.
  • Retrieve a list of all data classifications available in the current domain.


This API requires the Data Classification [com.glide.data_classification] plugin.

For more information, see Data Classification.

children.name: label
children.text: String
children.text2: The display label for the facet item or mapped query.

children.name: Example
children.text: function createMultiChoiceFacetFromKB(label, variable, values, orderBy){ if(!values || values.length == 0) return; var kbFacet = facetService.createMultiChoiceFacet(label, variable); var kbMap = {}; for(var i in values) { var key = values[i].label; var value = values[i].id; var parent = new KBParentData().getParentCategory(value, key); key = parent.join(' > '); kbMap[key] = value; } var labels = Object.keys(kbMap).sort(); for (i = 0; i < labels.length; i++) { var currentLabel = labels[i]; kbFacet.addFacetItem(currentLabel, kbMap[currentLabel]); //adds facet search options for each kbMap entry } }

children.name: void
children.text: Method does not return a value

children.name: valueObj
children.text: Object
children.text2:
The facet item or mapped query for the facet. Can only contain types String,
                Number, Boolean, and Double.

children.name: addFacetItem(String label, Object valueObj)
children.text: Adds facet items or mapped queries to a facets object.
children.text2: Before adding facet items to a facets object, create the facets object using the createFacet() or createMultiChoiceFacet() methods of the SPScriptedFacetService class.

name: SPScriptedFacet
text: Define facet items, filters, or mapped queries for a facets object.
text2:
The SPScriptedFacet API can only be used in a facet generation script in a Service Portal search source. The facet generation script is only visible when Is scripted source is selected.

There is no constructor for this class. Instead, use the createFacet() or createMultiChoiceFacet() methods of the SPScriptedFacetService class to generate a facets object.

children.name: Object
children.text:
Single choice facets object. Returns an error when:
  • A duplicate label or ID is found.
  • A label or ID is not defined.

children.name: label
children.text: String
children.text2: Label for the facet.

children.name: Example
children.text: var stateFacet = facetService.createFacet("State", "state");
children.text2:
Can only be used in a facet generation script in a Service Portal advanced search
        source.

children.name: id
children.text: String
children.text2: ID for the facet.

children.name: createFacet(String label, String id)
children.text: Creates a single choice facets object.
children.text2: After creating the facets object, add facet items or mapped queries to the facet using the addFacetItem() method of the SPScriptedFacet class.

children.name: Example
children.text: function createMultiChoiceFacetFromKB(label, variable, values, orderBy){ if(!values || values.length == 0) return; var kbFacet = facetService.createMultiChoiceFacet(label, variable); var kbMap = {}; for(var i in values) { var key = values[i].label; var value = values[i].id; var parent = new KBParentData().getParentCategory(value, key); key = parent.join(' > '); kbMap[key] = value; } var labels = Object.keys(kbMap).sort(); for (i = 0; i < labels.length; i++) { var currentLabel = labels[i]; kbFacet.addFacetItem(currentLabel, kbMap[currentLabel]); //adds facet search options for each kbMap entry } }

children.name: Object
children.text:
Multi choice facets object.

Returns an error when:

  • A duplicate label or ID is found.
  • A label or ID is not defined.

children.name: label
children.text: String
children.text2: Label for the facet.

children.name: id
children.text: String
children.text2: ID for the facet.

children.name: createMultiChoiceFacet(String label, String id)
children.text: Creates a multi choice facets object.
children.text2: After creating the facets object, add facet items or mapped queries to the facet using the addFacetItem() method of the SPScriptedFacet class.

name: SPScriptedFacetService
text: Generate a multi choice or single choice facets object for an advanced search source.
text2:
The SPScriptedFacetService API can only be used in a facet generation script in a Service Portal search source. The facet generation script is only visible when Is scripted source is selected.

There is no constructor for this class. Instead, use the createFacet() or createMultiChoiceFacet() methods to generate a facets object.

children.name: Output
children.text:
*** Script: tails
*** Script: heads
*** Script: tails
*** Script: heads
*** Script: tails
*** Script: heads
*** Script: tails
*** Script: tails
*** Script: tails
*** Script: tails

children.name: Example
children.text: new Stream(Math.random) .map(Math.round) .map(function (num) { return num === 1 ? 'heads' : 'tails'; }) .limit(10) .forEach(gs.info)
children.text2: This shows you how to create a Stream object based on a random number generator. Make sure to include the limit() method to avoid creating an infinite loop.

children.name: nextFn
children.text: Function
children.text2: A function that retrieves the next item in the stream.

children.name: Stream(Function nextFn)
children.text: Instantiates a Stream object.
children.text2: Instead of using this constructor, you can return a Stream object based on a query using the GlideQuery API.

children.name: Stream
children.text: Object used to interact with a stream of items such as records.

children.name: count
children.text: Number
children.text2: Number of records in each array returned from the stream.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var chunkResult = new GlideQuery('cmdb_ci_hardware') .select('asset', 'purchase_date') .limit(10) .chunk(5) // returns arrays of 5 sys_ids at a time .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(chunkResult));
children.text2: This  shows how to query a table and chunk the result into batches of arrays.

children.name: Example
children.text: var chunkResult = new global.GlideQuery('cmdb_ci_hardware') .select('sys_id') .map(function (device) { return device.sys_id; }) .chunk(5) // returns arrays of 5 sys_ids at a time .flatMap(function (deviceIds) { return new GlideQuery('cmdb_sam_sw_install') .where('installed_on', 'IN', deviceIds) .select('software_model', 'installed_on'); }) gs.info(JSON.stringify(chunkResult));
children.text2: This shows how to create a child query using batches of IDs. When you call the flatMap() method after using the chunk() method, the system iterates over the batch of records instead of each individual record.

children.name: chunk(Number count)
children.text:
Returns results in batches of arrays, each containing the number of records passed to
    the method.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the predicate function returns true for every item in the stream.

Valid values:
  • true: The predicate function returns true for every item in the stream.
  • false: The predicate function does not return true for every item in the stream.

children.name: predicate
children.text: Function
children.text2:
Predicate function to apply to every record or item inside the Stream object.
                The function must take each item in the stream as input and return a boolean.

children.name: Output
children.text: false

children.name: Example
children.text: var hasOnlyShortDescriptions = new global.GlideQuery('task') .whereNotNull('description') .select('description') .every(function (t) { return t.description.length < 10; }); gs.info(hasOnlyShortDescriptions);
children.text2: This  shows how to apply a predicate function to every item in a stream.

children.name: every(Function predicate)
children.text:
Applies a predicate function to every item in the Stream object. If the predicate
    returns true for every item in the stream, the method returns true. If the predicate returns
    false for any item in the stream, the method returns false.

children.name: Example
children.text: var shoutingTasks = new global.GlideQuery('task') .whereNotNull('description') .select('description') .filter(function (task) { return task.description.toUpperCase() === task.description; })
children.text2:
This  shows how to check all records in the Task table against a defined filter. If
        the records match the filter, the system returns the stream of records. Otherwise, it
        returns an empty Stream object.

children.name: Stream
children.text: Object used to interact with a stream of items such as records.

children.name: predicate
children.text: Function
children.text2:
Predicate function to apply to every record or item inside the Stream object.
                The function must take each item in the stream as input and return a
                boolean.

children.name: filter(Function predicate)
children.text:
Applies a predicate function to each item in the Stream object. If the predicate
    returns true, the method returns the stream. If the predicate returns false, it returns an empty
    Stream object.
children.text2: For better performance, use the where(), whereNotNull(), and whereNull() methods in the GlideQuery class instead of this method where possible. See GlideQuery.

children.name: predicate
children.text: Function
children.text2:
Optional. Predicate function to apply to the items inside the Stream object.
                The function must take each item in the stream as input and return a
                boolean.

children.name: Example
children.text: var UserOptional = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('active', true) .where('company.name', 'ServiceNow') .select() .find() .map(function (user) { return JSON.stringify(user); }) gs.info(UserOptional);
children.text2: This  shows how to return the first record from the stream.

children.name: Optional
children.text: Object containing the returned record.

children.name: find(Function predicate)
children.text:
Returns the first record or item in the Stream object that matches the predicate
    function. If no predicate function is provided, then the method returns the first record or item
    in the Stream.

Example
children.text: var records = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .where('last_login', '>', '2015-12-31') .select('first_name', 'last_name') .flatMap(function (u) { return new global.GlideQuery('task') .where('closed_by', u.sys_id) .select('closed_at', 'description') .map(function (t) { return { first_name: u.first_name, last_name: u.last_name, description: t.description, closed_at: t.closed_at }; }); }) .limit(5) .toArray(100); gs.info(JSON.stringify(records));

This  shows you how to query the User table and then create a child query from the
        result. This example executes an N+1 query, which can cause performance issues. Avoid this
        use case in a production environment.

Object containing the stream of records updated after applying the

Applies a function to every item in a stream. Returns another stream that you can

children.text2: Use this method instead of map() if the function returns a second stream of records.

Object containing the stream of records updated after applying the

children.name: Any
children.text: Accumulated total of all items returned by the reducer function.

children.name: reducerFn
children.text: Function
children.text2:
Function to apply to each item in the stream that reduces the stream to a single value. This function must take two arguments:
  • acc: Accumulator that accumulates all values returned by the function.
  • cur: Current item being accumulated in the array.

children.name: initialValue
children.text: Any

children.text:
Executes a reducer function on each item in the stream, resulting in single output
    value.
children.text2: This method is similar to the native JavaScript reduce() method. For more information, see w3schools documentation.

children.name: Boolean
children.text:
Flag that indicates whether the predicate function returned true for an item in the stream.

Valid values:
  • true: The predicate function returned true for an item in the stream.
  • false: The predicate function did not return true for an item in the stream.

children.name: predicate
children.text: Function
children.text2:
Predicate function to apply to the items inside the Stream object. Must return
                a Boolean value.

children.name: Example
children.text: var hasLongDescriptions = new global.GlideQuery('task') .whereNotNull('description') .select('description') .some(function (t) { return t.description.length > 1000; }); gs.info(hasLongDescriptions);

This  shows how to check whether any descriptions in the Task table are over 1,000
        characters long.

children.name: some(Function predicate)
children.text:
Applies a predicate function, a function that takes a single value and returns true or
    false, to each item in the stream. If the predicate returns true for any item in the stream, the
    method returns true.

children.name: count
children.text: Number
children.text2: The maximum number of items from the stream to return in the array.

children.name: Output
Example
children.text: var users = new global.GlideQuery('sys_user') .limit(10) .select('first_name', 'last_name') .toArray(50); gs.info(JSON.stringify(users));
children.text2: This  shows you how to transform a stream of records into a JavaScript array.

children.name: Array
children.text: Array containing the given number of items from the stream.

children.name: toArray(Number count)
children.text: Returns an array containing the given number of items from the stream.

name: Stream
text: The Stream API interacts with a stream of items such as records. For example, you can use the forEach() method to update the state of each record in a stream returned by the GlideQuery API.
text2:
You can get a Stream object in these ways:

  • Instantiate a Stream object using the constructor.
  • Return a Stream object from the GlideQuery.select() method. For more information, see GlideQuery.


This method is static and does not require an instance of the class: fromArray().

Use the Stream API in scoped or global server-side scripts. This API requires the GlideQuery [com.sn_glidequery] plugin.

Implementation

This API can work with the GlideQuery and Optional APIs in a builder pattern where the method calls chain together, each method building on the returned result of the previous method. Use methods to define the attributes of the query. The methods do not execute until you call a terminal method, a method that returns a query result, allowing you to define the requirements of the query before executing it.

If the query returns a single record, the system wraps the result in an Optional object. If the query returns a stream of records, the system wraps the result in a Stream object. These objects let you manage the result using a set of methods in each API.

For example, here's a script that performs a query on the Task table and groups the records by priority and returns groups with total reassignments greater than four.

var query = new global.GlideQuery('task')
    .where('active', true) //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "where" clause.
    .groupBy('priority') //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "group by" clause.
    .aggregate('sum', 'reassignment_count') //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "sum(reassignment_count)" clause.
    .having('sum', 'reassignment_count', '>', 4) //Returns new GlideQuery object with a "having reassignment_count > 4" clause.
    .select() //Returns a stream of records wrapped in a Stream object.  
    .toArray(10); //Terminal method in the Stream class that executes the query and returns the result.


Terminal methods

For performance reasons, a query only fetches data when you call a terminal method. These are the terminal methods from the Stream class:

  • every()
  • find()
  • forEach()
  • reduce()
  • some()
  • toArray()

name: v_query – Scoped, Global
text: Scriptable object that represents a query running against a remote table.
text2:
This API requires the Remote Tables plugin (com.glide.script.vtable) to be activated. Retrieving external data using remote tables and scripts.

Remote table rows are created using the v_table API.

children.name: Example
children.text: (function executeQuery (v_table, v_query) { // Parameters needed in the request body of the REST endpoint var requestBody = { 'financial_account':v_query.getParameter('financial_account') }; // Instantiate the RESTMessageV2 object var request = new sn_ws.RESTMessageV2(); // Set the HTTP method as "GET" request.setHttpMethod('get'); // URL of the endpoint on the bank application request.setEndpoint('https://<yourbankapphost>/api/getTransactionDetails'); // Request body as a string request.setRequestBody(JSON.stringify(requestBody)); // Call the REST endpoint var response = request.execute(); // Get the response body var responseBody = response.getBody(); // Parse the response body into an object var responseObj = JSON.parse(responseBody); // Store the response body into a virtual table v_table.addRow({ sys_id: gs.generateGUID(), amount: responseObj.amount, description: responseObj.description, posting_date: responseObj.posting_date, transaction_date: responseObj.transaction_date }); }) (v_table, v_query);
children.text2: The following shows how to use the RESTMessageV2 API to create and execute the REST call to an external bank application. The script shows how to use the addRow() method to store return results in a remote table.

children.name: row

JavaScript object containing field name and value map in which the key is the field name, for example, {number: "INC0001", sys_id: "a34"}.
{ "<field name>": "value" }

children.name: Boolean

Flag that indicates whether the row was added to the remote table.
Valid values:
  • true: Success.
  • false: Row was not added.

children.name: row.<field value>

children.text2:
Represents the value of the selected field. Although no fields are mandatory, provide the sys_id at a minimum.

Example listing only sys_id field and value:

{ "sys_id": "<uniqueID>" }

children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); //returns the root node of the document tree. var rootNode = xmlDoc.getDocumentElement(); gs.info(rootNode.getTextContent());

children.name: XMLNode
children.text: The document element.

children.name: getDocumentElement()
children.text:
Gets the document element node of the XMLdocument2 object. The document element node is
    the root node.

children.name: XMLNode
children.text: The first node.

children.text: String
children.text2: The xPath to obtain the node from.

children.name: Output
children.text: abcd1234

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var foo = xmlDoc.getFirstNode('/test/one/two'); gs.info(foo.getTextContent());

children.name: getFirstNode(String xPath)
children.text: Gets the first node in the specified xPath.
children.text2:
This method only supports a subset of predicate xPath expressions. For example, assume the following document:

<store> 
    <resources company="ABC Inc"> 
        <resources type="servers" /> 
    </resources> 
    <resources company="XYZ Inc"> 
        <resource type="bookstore"> 
            <book> 
                <title>Windows</title> 
                <price>10</price> 
            </book> 
            <book year="2009"> 
                <title>Harry Potter</title> 
                <price>50</price> 
            </book> 
            <book year="1999"> 
                <title>Learning XML</title> 
                <price>120</price> 
            </book> 
            <book year="2019"> 
                <title>Learning Java</title> 
                <price>99</price> 
            </book> 
        </resource> 
    </resources> 
</store>

This method supports the following xPath expressions with predicates:

"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[@year='1999']", 
"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[@year]", 
"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[price > 100]"

However, it does not support the following xPath expressions with predicates:

"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[2]", 
"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[last()]", 
"/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book[position()>2]"

To work around this, use xPath without predicates, such as "/store/resources/resource[@type='bookstore']/book") and then filter the nodes in the script using the getFirstNode() and getNextNode() methods.

children.name: Output
children.text:
abcd1234

another

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var foo = xmlDoc. getFirstNode('/test/one/two'); var foo2 = xmlDoc.getNextNode(foo); gs.info(foo.getTextContent()); gs.info(foo2.getTextContent());

children.name: XMLNode
children.text: Current XML node.

children.name: getNode(String xPath)
children.text: Gets the node specified in the xPath.
children.text2: Note: This method is intended for use with small documents since it parses the entire document to match the xPath expression. If the document is too large, an out of memory error may occur. For large documents, use the getFirstNode(String xPath) and getNextNode(Object current) methods, which are designed to stream through the document without parsing the entire document.

children.text: String
children.text2: XPath of the text to obtain.

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); gs.info(xmlDoc.getNodeText("//two"));

children.text: Text children in the XPath.

Gets all the text child nodes from the node referenced in the specified

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var rootNode = xmlDoc.getDocumentElement();

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); //returns the root node of the document tree. var rootNode = xmlDoc.getDocumentElement(); //returns org.w3c.dom.Element // sets the root node as the current element xmlDoc.setCurrentElement(rootNode);

children.name: setNamespaceAware(Boolean aware)
children.text:
When set to true, the XMLDocument2 object processes the document with XML
    namespaces.
children.text2: If you don't set this, an XML document with namespaces won't be enumerated correctly, and an XPath search would fail.

Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); gs.info(xmlDoc.toString());

children.name: toString()
children.text: Returns a string containing the XML.

name: XMLDocument2
text:
XMLDocument2 is a JavaScript Object wrapper for parsing and extracting XML data from an
  XML string.
text2:
Use this JavaScript class to create an object from an XML string, usually a return value from a web-service invocation, or the XML payload of ECC Queue. Using the XMLDocument2 object in a JavaScript business rule lets you query values from the XML elements and attributes directly.

An XML string has a tree structure, and the parts of the structure are called nodes. An XMLDocument2 object deals with two node types, element, and document element. An element node is a node with a name and possibly attributes and child nodes. A document-element node is the root node of the XML tree. It is the only node without a parent node.

Note: This API works for scoped or global applications.

children.name: attribute
children.text: String
children.text2: Name of the attribute.

children.name: Output
children.text2: xxx

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//two'); gs.info(node.getAttribute('att'));

children.name: String
children.text: The attribute's value.

children.name: getAttribute(String attribute)
children.text: Gets the value of the attribute.

children.name: Object
children.text:
Contains name-value pairs where the name is the attribute and the value is the
                attribute's value.

children.name: getAttributes()
children.text:
Returns an object containing the node's attributes as properties with
    values.

children.name: XMLNodeIterator
children.text: The node iterator object.

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); var iter= node.getChildNodeIterator(); gs.info(iter.hasNext());

children.name: getChildNodeIterator()
children.text:
Gets a XMLNodeIterator object that can be used to walk through the list of child
    nodes.

children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + "<one>" + "<two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + "<three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + "<two>another</two>" + "</one>" + "<number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); gs.info(node.getFirstChild());

children.name: getFirstChild()
children.text: Gets the node's first child node.

children.name: Output
children.text: <two>another</two>

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + "<one>" + "<two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + "<three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + "<two>another</two>" + "</one>" + "<number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); gs.info(node.getLastChild());

children.name: XMLNode
children.text: The node's last child.

children.name: getLastChild()
children.text: Gets the node's last child node.

children.name: Output
children.text2: two

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//two'); gs.info(node.getNodeName());

children.name: String
children.text: The node's name.

children.name: getNodeName()
children.text:
Gets the node's name. A node's name is determined by the node type. A document-element
    node's name is #document. A text node's name is #text. An element node's name is the element's
    name.

children.name: Output
children.text2: null

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//two'); gs.info(node.getNodeValue());

children.name: String
children.text: The node's value.

children.name: getNodeValue()
children.text:
Gets the node's value. A node's value is determined by the node type. Element and
    document-element nodes return null.

children.name: String
children.text: The text content of the current node.

children.name: Output
children.text2: abcd1234

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmldoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmldoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmldoc.getNode('//one/two'); gs.info(node.getTextContent());

children.name: getTextContent()
children.text:
Gets the text content of the current node. The text content of a node consists of all
    the node's child text nodes

children.text: String
children.text2: The name of the attribute to check.

children.name: Output
children.text2: true

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//two'); gs.info(node.hasAttribute('att'));

children.text: True if the node has the attribute.

Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); gs.info(node.toString());

children.name: String
children.text: The string value of the current node.

children.name: toString()
children.text: Returns the string value of the current node.

name: XMLNode
text:
The scoped XMLNode API allows you to query values from XML nodes. XMLNodes are extracted
  from XMLDocument2 objects, which contain XML strings.
text2: There are no constructors for creating a stand alone instance of an XMLNode object. Instead, use the createElement() method of XMLDocument2, which adds a node to an existing document.

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); var iter= node.getChildNodeIterator(); gs.info(iter.hasNext());

children.name: Boolean
children.text: True if the iteration has more elements.

children.name: hasNext()
children.text: Returns true if the iteration has more elements.

children.name: Output
children.text:
Node name: #text
Node value:     
Node name: two
Node value: null
Node name: #text
Node value:     
Node name: three
Node value: null
Node name: #text
Node value:     
Node name: two
Node value: null
Node name: #text
Node value:

children.name: Example
children.text: var xmlString = "<test>" + " <one>" + " <two att=\"xxx\">abcd1234</two>" + " <three boo=\"yah\" att=\"yyy\">1234abcd</three>" + " <two>another</two>" + " </one>" + " <number>1234</number>" + "</test>"; var xmlDoc = new XMLDocument2(); xmlDoc.parseXML(xmlString); var node = xmlDoc.getNode('//one'); var iter= node.getChildNodeIterator(); while(iter.hasNext()) { var n = iter.next(); gs.info('Node name: ' + n.getNodeName()); gs.info('Node value: ' + n.getNodeValue()); }

children.name: XMLNode
children.text: The next element in the iteration.

children.name: next()
children.text:
Gets the next element in the iteration. The returned element may be a #text node for
    the spaces/tabs if XML is "pretty formatted".

name: XMLNodeIterator
text:
The scoped XMLNodeIterator class allows you to iterate through a node of a XML
  document.
text2: There are no constructors for creating a stand alone instance of a XMLNodeIterator object. To create a XMLNodeIterator object use the getChildNodeIterator() method of the XMLNode object.
